statement: Tina Turner is gravely ill due to stomach or intestinal cancer, a stroke, and/or rejection of a kidney or liver transplant.

title: Was a Walrus Really Found Sleeping atop a Submarine?
subtitle: The giant marine mammal apparently spent quite a bit of time on the sub and even enjoyed a nap. But looks can be deceiving.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a man standing behind a sleeping walrus atop a submarine.

title: Did North Carolina Ban Sharia Law and Make It a 'Criminal Offense'?
subtitle: Social media memes in spring 2019 exaggerated the implications of a law passed by the North Carolina legislature almost six years earlier.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: North Carolina prohibited and criminalized the use of Sharia law.

title: Did Washington State Sen. Maureen Walsh Say Nurses 'Play Cards' for a Large Part of Their Working Day?
subtitle: The Republican state senator attracted nationwide coverage and widespread criticism in April 2019, but what did she actually say?
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Washington state Sen. Maureen Walsh said nurses "play cards for a considerable amount of the day."

title: Did the Obama Transition Team Keep a 'List of Muslims For Top Jobs'?
subtitle: It's unclear why a story from the 2016 election cycle was circulating in 2019.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Obama transition team kept a list of Muslims for top jobs.

title: Does the Family of Former Attorney General Eric Holder Own an Abortion Clinic?
subtitle: A seven-year-old cluster of news reports got a new lease of life on Facebook in April 2019.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Family relatives of former U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder own property used as an abortion clinic.

title: Did Republican Texas Legislators Advance a Bill That Would 'Allow Doctors to Refuse to Treat LGBT People'?
subtitle: Texas Senate Bill 17 provoked debate and attracted nationwide attention in the spring of 2019.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: If implemented, the provisions of Texas Senate Bill 17 would "allow doctors to refuse LGBTQ patients."

title: Can Canadians Be Fined $1,000 for 'Eating While Driving Starting Next Month'?
subtitle: A viral story lacked context about the implementation of a new driving law in province of Ontario.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Canadians can be fined $1,000 for eating while driving.

title: Is Walmart Selling 'Satanic' Items?
subtitle: Items with "satanic" themes can indeed be purchased through the retail giant's website.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Walmart is selling 'satanic' items.

title: Did Congress Pass the 22nd Amendment in Order to 'Make Sure FDR Did Not Get Re-Elected'?
subtitle: Critics seized upon remarks made by Democrat U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez during an appearance on MSNBC in March 2019.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The U.S. Congress passed the 22nd Amendment in order to "make sure President Franklin D. Roosevelt did not get re-elected."

title: Do Sens. Warren, Booker, Harris and Sanders Pass Fewer Bills Than Other Senators?
subtitle: A meme attempting to paint various politicians as ineffective lawmakers uses outdated, cherry-picked statistics and omits important context.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A text-based meme accurately portrays various Democrat politicians' success rate at passing legislation.

title: Did 'Muslim Militants' Kill 120 Christians in Nigeria in February/March 2019?
subtitle: News reports in the aftermath of the Christchurch, New Zealand, massacre presented a woefully incomplete description of a complicated conflict.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Muslim militants killed 120 Christians in Nigeria during a three-week period in February and March 2019.

title: Will U.S. Citizens Need a New Visa to Visit Europe Starting in 2021?
subtitle: What exactly is the European Union planning? And what, if anything, did they announce in March 2019?
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In March 2019, the European Union announced that, beginning in 2021, certain non-European travellers (including U.S. citizens) would require a visa to visit Europe.

title: Did a Muslim Student Set Fire to a Christian School to 'Protest' Trump?
subtitle: A years-old incident, an unrelated photograph, and some misleading reporting were mixed together and spread on social media after dozens of Muslims were killed in a mass shooting in New Zealand.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A Muslim student set fire to a Christian school in protest of U.S. President Donald Trump.

title: Did Patrick Moore, a Doubter of Anthropogenic Climate Change, Co-Found Greenpeace?
subtitle: We definitely know that he was an early member of Greenpeace.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Patrick Moore, who once described anthropogenic climate change as “fake science” on the morning opinion program "Fox and Friends," co-founded the environmental action group Greenpeace.

title: Are Chicken Nuggets Made From Feathers Heading to Store Shelves?
subtitle: Some readers were a little confused, or maybe just grossed out, about a potential future food.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A company is developing a lab-grown chicken nugget made from feathers.

title: Does This Image Show 'Negro Skin Shoes'?
subtitle: Plenty of evidence exists of various personal items made from human skin in the 19th century.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a pair of "negro skin shoes."

title: Did Oprah Winfrey Promote the 'Shout Your Abortion' Campaign?
subtitle: Conservative and pro-life observers criticized the media mogul in 2018 and 2019, but what did Oprah actually say?
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 2018, Oprah Winfrey promoted a pro-choice online campaign called #ShoutYourAbortion.

title: Did U.S. Sen. Mitch McConnell Increase His Net Worth by 'Nearly $2.4 Million Every Year for a Decade'?
subtitle: A meme based on a 2014 campaign ad has continued to make the online rounds years later.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Senator Mitch McConnell increased his net worth by $2.4 million every year for a decade while in office.

title: Did Planned Parenthood Harvest the Brain from a Living, Late-Term Fetus?
subtitle: A tweet by a high-profile Fox News personality breathed new life into an old controversy.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A video documents that Planned Parenthood harvested the brain from a living, late-term aborted fetus.

title: Did Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez 'Chase' Amazon Out of Her NYC District?
subtitle: The newly elected congresswoman from New York was a vocal opponent of Amazon's plans, as were many others.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez "chased" Amazon away from establishing a second headquarters in her district.

title: Can a Mobile Phone's Bluetooth Sensor Be Used to Detect Card Skimmers?
subtitle: A viral Facebook post gave readers advice on how to avoid having their credit card details stolen while refueling.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Cellphone bluetooth sensors can detect the presence of credit card skimmers in gas pumps.

title: Did Democrats Pass a Bill That Funds College for 'Illegal Immigrants' Using Taxpayer Money?
subtitle: "Investment is squandered when higher education is placed out of reach, and it is a huge disservice to students and all New Yorkers."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Democratic legislators passed a bill to fund college for undocumented immigrants using taxpayer money.

title: Was Jacob Walter Anderson Fined $400 for Repeatedly Raping a Baylor Student?
subtitle: Social media users responded in outrage to the penalties handed down to a Baylor University fraternity president accused of rape.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Jacob Walter Anderson repeatedly raped a young woman but received only a $400 fine and deferred probation as punishment.

title: Did a Man Escape a Murder Charge Because of New York's Reproductive Health Act?
subtitle: Anthony Hobson, who killed his girlfriend and her unborn child, was originally going to be charged with both unlawful abortion and second degree murder.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A man who stabbed his pregnant girlfriend “won't be charged” because of New York's recently enacted Reproductive Health Act.

title: Is President Trump Planning a Military Parade for the Fourth of July?
subtitle: As in the past, it's unclear whether a military parade will in fact materialize.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Trump is planning a military parade for the 4th of July in 2019.

title: Did President Trump Laud the 'Abolition of Civil Rights'?
subtitle: What exactly did President Trump say - and what did he mean to say - at the 2019 National Prayer Breakfast?
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: During remarks in February 2019, Trump touted the "abolition of civil rights" as one of the greatest accomplishments in the history of the United States.

title: Did Maroon 5 Donate Their Super Bowl Halftime Show Earnings to Charity?
subtitle: A charitable donation didn't spare the band from criticism for accommodating the NFL.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Maroon 5 donated their entire 2019 Super Bowl halftime show performance earnings to charity.

title: Did Kamala Harris Once Boast About Prosecuting a Homeless Mother?
subtitle: A nine-year-old speech resurfaced online in January 2019, after the California Democrat announced her presidential ambitions.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: U.S. Senator Kamala Harris bragged, boasted or laughed about prosecuting a homeless single mother in a January 2010 speech.

title: Did the RNC Block Challengers to Trump's Re-Election?
subtitle: The Republican National Committee passed a resolution supporting President Trump at a winter 2019 gathering but didn't completely preclude an intra-party challenge.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The Republican National Committee has barred any intraparty challenges to President Donald Trump's bid for re-election.

title: Did Rep. Ilhan Omar Call for Lighter Sentences for Would-Be ISIS Recruits?
subtitle: The Minnesota Democrat sent a letter to a U.S. District Court judge in 2016. What exactly did she write?
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: U.S. Representative Ilhan Omar has advocated shorter prison sentences for individuals "caught trying to join ISIS."

title: Is a 'Nancy Pelosi Crime Family' Meme Accurate?
subtitle: And where does the 'Pelosi Crime Family' fall on a scale of 'innocent' to 'Gambino'?
author: Dan Evon
statement: A meme accurately describes 'The Nancy Pelosi Crime Family.'

title: Was Roger Stone an Adviser to President Richard Nixon?
subtitle: Stone's arrest has prompted comparisons between his role in both Nixon's and Trump's presidential campaigns.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Roger Stone was an "aide" or an "adviser" to 37th U.S. President Richard Nixon.

title: Did New York Pass a Bill Legalizing Abortions Up to Birth?
subtitle: Opponents claimed the law "strips unborn children of their rights and jeopardizes women's health by allowing non-physicians to perform" abortions
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The state of New York has passed a bill legalizing abortion up to birth.

title: Did President Donald Trump Run TV Ads Asking Border Wall Supporters to Call an 800 Number?
subtitle: "We need to deliver the voices of millions of Americans that we support President Trump, and it starts with your phone call."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In January 2019, President Donald Trump ran a television commercial that urged supporters of his proposed border wall to call an 800 number and take part in a survey.

title: Did Second Lady Karen Pence Work at a School That Bans LGBT Teachers and Students?
subtitle: The wife of Vice President Mike Pence resumed her work as an art teacher at the Immanuel Christian School in Northern Virginia in January 2019.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In January 2019, Second Lady Karen Pence began working as a teacher at a school that bans LGBT teachers and students.

title: Has the FDA Halted Food Inspections Because of the Government Shutdown?
subtitle: Some inspectors have returned to resume their duties, but it's unclear for how long.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Food and Drug Administration has halted all food inspections due to the federal government shutdown.

title: Was Wall Street Originally the Site of a 'Border Wall' Meant to Protect New Amsterdam?
subtitle: Social media memes compared a defensive wall built along the northern border of New Amsterdam during the 17th century to President Donald Trump's border wall.
author: David Emery
statement: In the 17th century, New Amsterdam built a protective wall along its northern perimeter (analogous to Trump's border wall) to keep "bad hombres" out, but it failed to achieve its stated purpose in that the British successfully invaded the city by sea.

title: Did the Company That Makes Marlboros Announce They Intend to Stop Producing Cigarettes?
subtitle: Philip Morris International sells the iconic brand outside the United States, and has for years expressed a plan to end production of cigarettes altogether.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In January 2019, the company that makes Marlboros announced their intention to stop producing cigarettes altogether.

title: Was a Sculpture 'Celebrating' Saudi Arabia Erected at Ground Zero?
subtitle: Outrage posts on clickbait web sites didn't tell the full story of an art exhibition.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A sculpture "celebrating" Saudi Arabia was erected at Ground Zero.

title: Did Trump Order FEMA to 'Send No More Money' for California Wildfire Aid?
subtitle: President Trump has threatened to cut off aid to California unless authorities changed their forest management policies. Did he go one step further in early 2019?
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In January 2019, President Donald Trump ordered FEMA to stop or cancel funding for its disaster assistance efforts in California.

title: Does Lack of Affordable Healthcare Kill More People in America Than Terrorism and Illegal Immigration?
subtitle: A widely-shared Facebook meme challenged readers to reevaluate their political priorities about immigration and health care.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Lack of affordable healthcare accounts for a greater number of deaths per year than do terrorist attacks and illegal immigration combined.

title: Were 17,000 “Criminal Aliens” and 6,000 MS-13 Gang Members Arrested in 2018?
subtitle: This claim, made on the RNC's “Border Facts” page, muddied several numbers to make a misleading argument.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: In 2018, over 17,000 adults arrested at the border had prior criminal records, including 6,000 gang members (many of them MS-13).

title: Was Senator Chuck Schumer Caught Taking $1 Million in 'Excessive Contributions'?
subtitle: Trump supporters raised the issue of past campaign finance violations to question Schumer's fitness to hold office in December 2018.
author: David Emery
statement: In 1998, Senator Chuck Schumer was caught taking $1 million in excessive campaign contributions and failing to properly disclose $4.6 million in expenses, for which he was fined $138,000.

title: Was Joshua Wilkerson Murdered by a DACA Beneficiary?
subtitle: A tragic death which was nonetheless unrelated to the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals policy.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Joshua Wilkerson was murdered by an immigrant who was staying in the U.S. due to the DACA policy.

title: Did Trump Say He Found 12-Year-Old Paris Hilton Beautiful and Sexually Attractive?
subtitle: "Somebody who a lot of people don't give credit to but in actuality is really beautiful is Paris Hilton."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Donald Trump said he found 12-year-old Paris Hilton to be beautiful and sexually attractive.

title: Are Mobile Phone Users Vulnerable to 'SIM Swap' Fraud Through Phone Calls?
subtitle: A social media post about a resurgent scam misstates the problem, but the form of fraud is very real.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Cellphone users are being increasingly targeted by a "SIM swap fraud," in which their phones will briefly stop working before they receive a call tricking them into surrendering their information.

title: Did These Politicians Build Walls Around Their Homes?
subtitle: A meme attempting to equate a national border wall with home security featured provocative images of politicians' residences.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Photographs show walls around the homes of President Obama, Hillary Clinton, Nancy Pelosi, Dianne Feinstein and Maxine Waters.

title: Is Olivia Newton-John Dying of Cancer?
subtitle: Celebrity gossip websites reported in December 2018 that the 70-year-old singer had only days or weeks to live.
author: David Emery
statement: Singer Olivia Newton-John hovers close to death due to a recurring bout of cancer and has only weeks to live.

title: Immigrants vs. 'Gimmegrants'
subtitle: A comparison of two different photographs that appear to have nothing in common.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A meme contrasts the attitudes of two different sets immigrants to the U.S.

title: Did a Survey Reveal That People Want a 'Gender Neutral' Santa Claus?
subtitle: A survey by a graphic-design company may not accurately represent the views of the public at large.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: According to a survey, some 18% of respondents want Santa Claus to be "gender neutral."

title: Did the Trump Administration Auction Off 150,000 Acres of Public Land for Fracking?
subtitle: Activists warned that the Bureau of Land Management was ignoring scientific evidence in opening the land up to business interests.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: President Donald Trump's administration auctioned 150,000 acres of public land off in December 2018, making that land open to fracking activities.

title: Did Ruth Bader Ginsburg Cite 'Population Growth' Concerns When Roe v. Wade Was Decided?
subtitle: The Supreme Court justice's remarks in a 2009 interview have led to accusations that the Supreme Court justice is a proponent of eugenics.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: U.S. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg said that she approved of abortion as a means of population control.

title: Did Several Entities Related to President Trump Face Criminal Investigation in 2018?
subtitle: A popular tweet listed no fewer than six Trump-related entities supposedly under the legal microscope.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A half dozen Trump-related entities were under criminal investigation in December 2018.

title: Is ALDI Offering Homeless People Free Food on Christmas Eve?
subtitle: Social media users avidly shared a meme that was well-meaning but light on details.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: ALDI offers free food to homeless people at their stores after 4 PM on Christmas Eve.

title: Did Donald Trump Acknowledge the Threat of Climate Change to His Irish Golf Course?
subtitle: The 45th president has been adamant and consistent in describing global warming and climate change as a "hoax."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: President Donald Trump, in applying for permission to build a wall at his golf course in Ireland, warned against the threat of coastal erosion caused by global warming.

title: Did Mexican Authorities Arrest and Torture a U.S. Marine for Accidentally Crossing the Border?
subtitle: A viral tweet over-simplified a complicated 2014 episode in the context of the 2018 "migrant caravan."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 2014, Mexican authorities arrested and tortured a U.S. Marine for "accidentally crossing the border," tying him to a bed for nine months in the process.

title: Did Netflix Announce They Will Be Removing 'Friends' from Their Streaming Catalog?
subtitle: The online streaming service caused consternation in December 2018 when they briefly signalled the hit 90's sitcom would no longer be available after 1 January 2019.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Netflix announced that 'Friends' would no longer be available for customers to stream after the end of 2018.

title: Did Matthew Whitaker Say That Muslims, Jews, and Atheists Shouldn't Be Judges?
subtitle: “No religious test shall ever be required as a qualification to any office or public trust under the United States.”
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker said that Muslims, Jews, and atheists shouldn't be judges.

title: Did Tomi Lahren Say Children Getting Tear Gassed Was the “Highlight” of Her Thanksgiving?
subtitle: A tear-gassing shouldn't be the highlight of anyone's day, victim or otherwise.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Tomi Lahren said that watching children being hit with tear gas "was the highlight” of her Thanksgiving weekend.

title: Did Barack Obama Say Becoming Donald Trump Was the American Dream?
subtitle: A young Barack Obama invoked Donald Trump's name as reflective of Americans' optimism, but not quite of the 'American dream.'
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Barack Obama once wrote that becoming Donald Trump was the American dream.

title: PETA Founder Ingrid Newkirk on Euthanizing Animals
subtitle: A viral Facebook meme contained some unflattering statements attributed to the controversial animal rights activist Ingrid Newkirk.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Four quotations attributed to PETA president and co-founder Ingrid Newkirk in a viral November 2018 meme are authentic.

title: Did Democrat Rep. Eric Swalwell 'Suggest Nuking' Gun Owners Who Resist Confiscation?
subtitle: Conservative web sites and commentators pounced on a tweet which the Democratic Congressman insisted was no more than a joke.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In November 2018, Democratic U.S. Representative Eric Swalwell suggested launching nuclear weapons against gun-owners who refused to hand over or sell semi-automatic rifles to the U.S. government.

title: Are Indonesian Teens Drinking Boiled, Bloody Menstrual Pads to Get “High” in a “New Trend”?
subtitle: Media outlets have taken a voyeuristic look at child poverty in the poorest parts of Indonesia and repackaged it as a viral “teens do dumb things to get high” story for clicks.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Boiling menstrual pads and drinking the water to get “high” or “drunk” is an alarming new trend amongst Indonesian teens.

title: Did Goodwill Offer Free Supplies to Wildfire Victims Throughout California?
subtitle: Various local Goodwills in California were offering assistance to residents forced to flee the Camp Fire in November 2018, but it was not a universal, statewide policy.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Goodwill offered free clothing, blankets and toiletries to anyone fleeing the November 2018 California wildfires, throughout the state.

title: Did a Broward County Employee Witness Elections Staff Filling Out Blank Ballots?
subtitle: A temp worker signed an affidavit in 2016 stating she saw elections officials filling out blank absentee ballots.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A Broward County employee witnessed elections staff filling out blank absentee ballots.

title: Did California Governor Jerry Brown Veto a Wildfire Management Bill, Increasing the Risk of Wildfires?
subtitle: A conservative political web site drew a link between the Democrat's rejection of a legislative proposal in 2016, and the prevalence and risk of wildfires in the following two years.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Jerry Brown vetoed a wildfire management bill in 2016, contributing to the prevalence and risk of wildfires in the ensuing two years.

title: Are 300 'Known Convicts and Gang Members' Among the Migrant Caravan?
subtitle: A vague U.S. government press release ambiguously stated that some 270 people with criminal histories were "along the caravan route."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Department of Homeland Security determined that 300 criminals were traveling in the Central American migrant caravan.

title: Did Stacey Abrams Admit Her Plans May Require Georgians to 'Turn Their Guns In'?
subtitle: "The fundamental responsibility is commonsense gun safety legislation in Georgia, making sure we get dangerous weapons off the streets."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Georgia Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams admitted her plans could force Georgians to turn over their guns.

title: Did Democrats Elect Four Horrible People?
subtitle: Criticisms of four 2018 Democratic election winners included in a meme are mostly subjective or unsubstantiated.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Democrats elected a domestic abuser, a woman who married her brother, a man who hired underage prostitutes, and a woman who is dumber than a salamander.

title: Does President Trump Have Financial Interests in Saudi Arabia?
subtitle: In response to Trump's tweet claiming that he has no such financial interests, social media users shared a Fox News Research tweet highlighting Trump's business dealings with the Saudis.
author: David Emery
statement: Despite his claims to the contrary, President Trump has ongoing financial interests in Saudi Arabia.

title: Did the Whole Migrant Caravan Turn Down Mexico's Offer of Jobs, Medical Care and Education?
subtitle: Some members of the caravan accepted the offer, some spurned it, and some returned home.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The entire Central American migrant caravan rejected Mexico's offer of jobs, medical care and education.

title: Did an MSNBC Crew Prevent a Disabled Veteran from Voting by Blocking a Handicapped Parking Spot?
subtitle: A television news crew was inconsiderate in blocking handicapped parking spaces but didn't actually prevent a disabled vet from voting.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: An MSNBC crew blocked a handicapped parking space outside a polling station in Houston, preventing a disabled U.S. Air Force veteran from voting.

title: Did Melania Trump's One-Day Stay at a Cairo Hotel Cost the U.S. Government $95,000?
subtitle: Some news reports got certain important details wrong about a State Department payment to the Semiramis Intercontinental Hotel in October 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: First Lady Melania Trump's one-day stay at a hotel in Cairo cost the U.S. government $95,050.

title: Did Armed Black Panthers Lobby and Intimidate on Behalf of Stacey Abrams?
subtitle: Misinformation runs rampant during election time, either through deliberate campaigns or inadvertent error.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Armed Black Panthers lobbied for Georgia gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams and attempted to intimidate residents into voting for her.

title: Did a Montana Libertarian End His Senate Run and Endorse a Republican?
subtitle: Rick Breckenridge reversed course on his announcement one day before the November 2018 midterm election.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A Libertarian candidate for a U.S. Senate seat in Montana ended his run and endorsed a Republican.

title: Did Andrew Gillum Suspend His Campaign for Governor of Florida?
subtitle: A small difference between two similar words caused confusion among readers about the Florida governor's race in the wake of a tragic event.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Tallahassee mayor Andrew Gillum has suspended his campaign for governor of Florida.

title: Did Beto O'Rourke's Staff Use Campaign Money to Help Migrants in El Paso?
subtitle: A controversial right-wing activist published yet another "sting" video which left out significant relevant information.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Undercover video footage shows that Beto O'Rourke campaign staff illegally used campaign resources to provide food, supplies and transportation to Central American migrants.

title: Did Pharrell Williams Send President Trump a 'Cease and Desist' Letter for Using His Song 'Happy'?
subtitle: The songwriter and producer criticized the president for playing the hit song after a mass shooting at a synagogue in Pittsburgh, but Trump wasn't responsible for the choice of music.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Lawyers for Pharrell Williams sent Donald Trump a "cease and desist" letter after the president played the song "Happy" before a speech on 27 October.

title: Can Southwest and American Airlines Passengers Collect Money from a Lawsuit Settlement?
subtitle: A website urging certain travelers to register advises that "it may not be economically practical" for them to collect cash stemming from a real court case.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Certain travelers who used American or Southwest Airlines can collect money as part of a consolidated lawsuit settlement.

title: Was Cesar Sayoc an Obama-Supporting Stripper Before Trump's Rise?
subtitle: Cesar Sayoc, Jr., the alleged anti-Democrat mail bomber, was a stripper at various points in his life, but there is no evidence that he ever held pro-Obama views.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Cesar Sayoc, the man accused of mailing bombs to prominent Democratic lawmakers and media organizations critical of President Trump, used to be a stripper and was “long known to support Obama.”

title: Are Texas Voting Machines Switching People's Votes?
subtitle: Social media rumors report that voting machines in Texas are changing voters' selections to the opposite party's candidate in the state's U.S. Senate race.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Voting machines in Texas are changing voters' selections to the opposite party's candidate in a U.S. Senate race.

title: Does USPS Never Deliver Mail Directly to People Under Secret Service Protection?
subtitle: The Secret Service appears to have a policy of screening packages intended for its protectees, but this was not proof of a "false flag" operation.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: News media claims of bombs sent by mail to the Clintons and Obamas were false because USPS doesn't deliver mail to persons under Secret Service protection.

title: Did the 82nd Airborne Division Receive Word They Are Being Deployed to the Border?
subtitle: A social media rumor held that the vaunted airborne division was being sent to the Mexican border in response to a Central American migrant caravan.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The 82nd Airborne received word they are being deployed to the U.S.-Mexico border as a migrant caravan moves through Mexico.

title: Are Uber and Lyft Offering Voters Free Rides to the Polls for the 2018 Elections?
subtitle: Viral memes leave out significant nuance in the transportation companies' efforts to boost democratic participation in 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Uber and Lyft offer voters free rides to the polls on Election Day.

title: Were 100 ISIS Terrorists Caught in Guatemala as a Central American Caravan Headed to the US?
subtitle: Two different news stories separated in time and space created the impression that ISIS terrorists were traveling with a group of migrants from Central America.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A hundred ISIS terrorists were caught in Guatemala as a migrant caravan headed north to the United States.

title: Is Ford Preparing for Mass Layoffs After Losing $1 Billion to Trump's Trade Tariffs?
subtitle: A downturn in employment at Ford that some people want to blame on President Trump is disclaimed by the company itself.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Ford is laying workers off due to $1 billion in losses resulting from President Trump's new trade tariffs on metal imports.

title: Are 20 Percent of Homicide Victims with Restraining Orders Killed Soon After Obtaining Them?
subtitle: An image disseminated online cites part of a 2008 study on domestic violence but omits one key piece of information.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: 20 percent of women killed in Intimate Partner Homicides (IPH) who had restraining orders were killed within two days of obtaining it.

title: Did Georgia's Secretary of State 'Block' the Registrations of 53,000 Voters, Most of Them African-American?
subtitle: Left-wing Facebook pages weighed into Georgia's gubernatorial race with widely shared memes about alleged voter suppression in that state.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: As of October 2018, the office of Georgia Secretary of State Brian Kemp put on hold 53,000 voter registration applications, nearly 70 percent of them submitted by African Americans.

title: Is Michael Bublé 'Retiring' from Making Music?
subtitle: The Canadian singer-songwriter disclaimed a report quoting him as saying he would "leave at the very top."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Singer Michael Bublé's upcoming album will be his last, as he is retiring from making music.

title: Are Visitors to Virginia Prisons Barred from Wearing Tampons?
subtitle: A controversial Virginia Department of Corrections regulation regarding tampons was scuttled shortly before it took effect.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Visitors to prisons in Virginia are prohibited from wearing tampons or menstrual cups.

title: Does This Video Show the 'Left-Wing Mob' Committing Acts of Violence?
subtitle: A compilation of acts by a violent American "left-wing mob" uses a mixture of genuine, unrelated, and foreign footage.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows Democrats, referred to as an "angry left-wing mob" by President Trump, committing various acts of violence.

title: Did a Sheriff's Dept. Dress Arrestees in Nike Shirts for Their Mugshots?
subtitle: Was the use of Nike shirts for mugshots a subtle jab at the company's political choices, or a practical use of available material?
author: Dan Evon
statement: The Union County Sheriff's Department in Arkansas dressed numerous arrestees in Nike shirts for their mugshots as a jab at the company.

title: Does a Municipal Code Limit Trick-or-Treating to Children 12 and Younger?
subtitle: A viral image of one municipal ordinance regarding Halloween activities left viewers wondering whether police were going to be hauling off bigger youngsters for trick-or-treating.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Laws in some areas limit trick-or-treating to children 12 and younger.

title: Did Brett Kavanaugh Rule That a Raped Immigrant Teen Must Delay Her Abortion in Order to 'Think About it Maturely'?
subtitle: A widely-shared meme got the basic facts right about an October 2017 case involving the newest Supreme Court justice but embellished certain details.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Judge Brett Kavanaugh once ruled that a teenage immigrant who had been raped must take time to "think maturely" before undergoing an abortion.

title: Did a Middle School Display the Words 'F*ck Kavanaugh' on Their School Sign?
subtitle: A North Carolina middle school's sign was targeted by vandals, not "socialist teachers" trying to indoctrinate children.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Socialist teachers at South Charlotte Middle School put the message "Fuck Kavanaugh" on the school's sign.

title: Did a 'West Virginia Republican' Tell Women to 'Get Your Coat Hangers Ready' ?
subtitle: Parkersburg City Councilman Eric Barber made the "coat hanger" comment in a reply to a Facebook post about Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court confirmation.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Republican Eric Barber "celebrated" Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court confirmation by telling women to "get your coat hangers ready."

title: Did President Donald Trump Allow the Violence Against Women Act to Expire?
subtitle: The future of the Violence Against Women Act remains in jeopardy, but President Trump signed a nine-week extension of it just before it was due to lapse in 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: On 30 September 2018, the administration of President Donald Trump allowed the Violence Against Women Act to expire.

title: Did 100,000 Churches Call for the Kavanaugh Nomination to Be Withdrawn?
subtitle: An umbrella organization that represents thousands of local congregations issued  a statement on Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: At least 100,000 churches called for the withdrawal of Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court nomination.

title: Did Brett Kavanaugh 'Never Try a Case' Before Being Promoted from Law Clerk to Federal Judge?
subtitle: Kavanaugh hadn't spent much time in courtrooms when President George W. Bush nominated him to the DC Circuit in 2003, but he did have other legal experience.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: When President George W. Bush nominated him to the DC Circuit in 2003, Brett Kavanaugh had never tried a case in court and was promoted from a law clerk to a judgeship.

title: Is Christine Blasey Ford's Lawyer the Vice Chair of a 'Soros-Funded Org Opposing Kavanaugh'?
subtitle: Conspiratorial stories that link an organization on which Debra Katz serves as vice chair only tell part of the story.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Christine Blasey Ford's attorney, Debra Katz, serves as vice chair for a "Soros-funded organization" that opposes the Supreme Court confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh.

title: Did a UK University Ban Clapping at Student Events?
subtitle: The University of Manchester Student Union caught flak online for their proposal encouraging the use of British Sign Language at some events.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The student union at the University of Manchester instituted a ban on audible clapping during their events.

title: Did a Jury Find That a Cop Had Lied About a Fatal Shooting, But Brett Kavanaugh Threw Out the Verdict?
subtitle: Judge Brett Kavanaugh once ruled against a police shooting victim's family, blocking financial damages a jury awarded to them. But another part of that ruling was in the family's favor.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: After an off-duty police officer shot Brian Hundley, a jury found the officer had acted negligently and lied about the event, but Judge Brett Kavanaugh overturned the finding.

title: Does Kavanaugh Accuser Julie Swetnick Have a Restraining Order Against Her by a Former Boyfriend?
subtitle: An ex-boyfriend of Julie Swetnick filed a petition for a restraining order in 2001, but it was dismissed soon afterwards.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Kavanaugh accuser Julie Swetnick has a restraining order against her from an ex-boyfriend.

title: Did Nike Donate Vastly More to Republicans Than Democrats In the 2018 Election Cycle?
subtitle: News reports captured some of the important details about campaign contributions by Nike workers, but their headlines over-simplified the reality.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Nike donated three times more to Republicans than Democrats during the 2018 federal election cycle, up to August 2018.

title: Did President Trump Declare 4 October 'Bring Your Bible to School Day'?
subtitle: Conservative groups sponsor an annual event by that name, but the White House had no role in its creation.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: President Donald Trump declared 4 October "Bring Your Bible to School Day."

title: Is This Video of a Baby Being Violently Dunked in Water Real?
subtitle: A video showing an apparent "violent baptism" may appear shocking to some viewers, but the enthusiastic religious practice isn't unheard of.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a priest aggressively dunking a baby underwater during a baptism ceremony.

title: Did Franklin Graham Say 'Attempted Rape Is Not a Crime'?
subtitle: The evangelical conservative attempted to defend Brett Kavanaugh against an allegation that he committed a sexual assault as a teenager.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Rev. Franklin Graham said "attempted rape is not a crime" and that Brett Kavanaugh "respected" his victim by "not finishing."

title: Was Ilhan Omar Sworn in with Her Hand on the Quran?
subtitle: The Minnesota House of Representatives member used a commemorative Quran when she was ceremonially sworn into state office in 2017.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Ilhan Omar took part in her swearing-in to the Minnesota House of Representatives with her hand on a Quran.

title: Did Donald Trump Appoint the First Native American to Lead the Bureau of Indian Affairs?
subtitle: In August 2018, the U.S. Senate confirmed Tara Sweeney's appointment as Assistant Secretary for Indian Affairs.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: President Donald Trump appointed a Native American to run the Bureau of Indian Affairs, for the first time in U.S. history.

title: Did Chelsea Clinton Say It Would Be 'Un-Christian' to Protect Babies from Abortion?
subtitle: Clinton stoked controversy during a town hall radio broadcast by framing her stance in support of Roe v. Wade as 'deeply religious.'
author: David Emery
statement: Chelsea Clinton said it would be "un-Christian" to protect babies from abortion.

title: Did Pope Francis Say 'Exposing Pedophile Priests Is Satan's Work'?
subtitle: A disreputable web site chose to over-simplify and sensationalize a real homily delivered by the pope in September 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2018, Pope Francis said, in effect, that exposing pedophile priests is Satan's work.

title: Can Mobile Phone Users Update Their Voicemail Greetings Without Cellular Service?
subtitle: A "hurricane tip" circulating online would not, in fact, help everyone who might be affected by Hurricane Florence.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: In the event of a hurricane, mobile phone users can update their voicemail greetings even if they lose WiFi and cellular service.

title: Did Billy Graham's Daughter Say 9/11 Was 'God's Punishment' for Trans People, Evolution, and Secularism?
subtitle: During a 2016 radio interview, Anne Graham Lotz said 'God allows bad things to happen' like the September 11 attacks 'to show us that we need Him.'
author: David Emery
statement: Billy Graham's daughter, Anne Graham Lotz, said 9/11 was "God's punishment" for trans people, evolution, and secularism.

title: Were Inmates Abandoned at Orleans Parish Prison During Hurricane Katrina?
subtitle: Inmates at Orleans Parish Prison reported that they spent several days in flooded cells without food or water while awaiting rescue after Hurricane Katrina.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Inmates at Orleans Parish Prison spent several days in flooded cells while awaiting rescue after Hurricane Katrina, and hundreds of them disappeared.

title: Did President Trump Fist-Pump at a 9/11 Memorial?
subtitle: An image showing President Trump making an excited hand gesture on 11 September 2018 is genuine, but the photograph was snapped at an airport, not at a 9/11 memorial.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows President Trump making a "fist-pumping" hand gesture at a memorial for 9/11 victims.

title: Police Training and Police Killings: USA vs. the Nordic Countries
subtitle: A meme used mostly accurate stats to draw a somewhat questionable link between the duration of academy training and the use of deadly force by police.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A meme accurately compares police training and police killings in the United States and three Nordic countries.

title: Do Nike Factory Workers in Vietnam Earn 20 Cents Per Hour?
subtitle: Critics of Colin Kaepernick's endorsement deal with Nike shared viral claims about the pay and conditions of the company's factory workers.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Nike workers in Vietnam earn 20 cents per hour, work 70 to 80 hours per week, and are 80 percent female.

title: Did 125 Women Terminate Their Pregnancies During a Protest in South Korea?
subtitle: A photograph of women participating in a protest demanding the legalization of abortion in South Korea apparently captured most of them taking vitamins, not the abortion drug Mifepristone.
author: Dan Evon
statement: About 125 women took Mifepristone to terminate their pregnancies during a protest demanding the legalization of abortion in South Korea.

title: Did Ashton Kutcher's Software Help Rescue 6,000 Children from Sex Trafficking?
subtitle: Viral social media posts exaggerated the impact of the actor's much-lauded efforts to end child exploitation.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Software developed by Ashton Kutcher's charity has helped rescue around 6,000 children from sex trafficking.

title: Beto O'Rourke's 'Reality Check'
subtitle: A widely-shared Facebook meme offered allegations about a rising Democratic politician in Texas.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Claims made in a widely-shared 2018 meme about the personal and family history of Congressman Beto O'Rourke are accurate.

title: Have Researchers Warned About the Resurgence of a 'Flesh-Eating STD'?
subtitle: News reports in the U.S. featured headlines that sensationalized and misled readers about a single diagnosis of a very rare disease on a different continent.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In August 2018, "researchers" provided a "warning" about the spread of the "flesh-eating STD" donovanosis.

title: Did Ron Paul Call Congress “A Bunch of Psychopathic Authoritarians”?
subtitle: Ron Paul did use the words "psychopathic authoritarians" in his final address, but not specifically to describe the U.S. Congress or its members.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: In his farewell address to the House of Representatives in 2012, Ron Paul described Congress as “a bunch of psychopathic authoritarians.”

title: Did African-American Drivers Comprise 100% of the Traffic Arrests in Polk County, Iowa?
subtitle: An activist organization mistakenly reported a Des Moines police officer's 2017 traffic arrests were of exclusively African-American suspects.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: All of the drivers arrested in 282 traffic stops in Polk County, Iowa, were African-American.

title: Did a Florida Judge Give Vastly Different Sentences to Two Men, Whose Only Difference Was Their Race?
subtitle: A viral meme, based on a piece of investigative journalism, left out some important context in the cases of Chase Legleitner and Lamar Lloyd.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Florida 19th Judicial Circuit judge Sherwood "Chip" Bauer gave a black man 26 years in prison and a white man two years' time served, for the same crime, in the same circumstances.

title: Did Chelsea Clinton Say Legalizing Abortion Added Trillions to the Economy?
subtitle: After defending Roe v. Wade during a pro-choice panel discussion, Clinton was attacked by pro-life pundits who accused her of reducing abortion rights to a "pocketbook issue."
author: David Emery
statement: Chelsea Clinton said that legalizing abortion created trillions of dollars worth of economic growth.

title: Does This Video Show an Abnormally Large Leatherback Turtle?
subtitle: A video of a large leatherback turtle on a beach provided a misleading impression of the animal's true size.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows an abnormally large leatherback turtle on a beach.

title: Did Brett Kavanaugh Argue That People with Disabilities Could Be Forced to Undergo Elective Surgeries, Including Abortions?
subtitle: Advocates for the disabled community largely oppose Brett Kavanaugh, President Trump's nominee for the Supreme Court.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: U.S. Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh argued that disabled people could be forced to have elective surgeries, including abortions.

title: Did Aretha Franklin 'Work for' Donald Trump on Numerous Occasions?
subtitle: Remarking on the Queen of Soul's passing in August 2018, President Trump said, "She worked for me on numerous occasions."
author: David Emery
statement: The late songstress Aretha Franklin worked for Donald Trump on numerous occasions.

title: Were an American Couple Killed by Isis While Trying to 'Prove Humans Are Kind'?
subtitle: A widely-shared article potentially confused some readers about the motives of a couple murdered in Tajikistan in July 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Americans Jay Austin and Lauren Geoghegan were killed in Tajikistan while cycling through "Isis territory" in order to vindicate their belief in human kindness.

title: Was a 'Muslim Extremist' Granted Bail by a 'Liberal Democrat' Judge After Training Children to Shoot Up Schools?
subtitle: Despite Internet outrage saying otherwise, New Mexico "compound" defendant Siraj Ibn Wahhaj has not been released on bond, because he is being held on an out-of-state warrant.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A "liberal Democrat" judge released on bond a Muslim extremist who trained children at a New Mexico compound to become school shooters.

title: Does Public Law 92-313 Allow Americans to Claim 'Federal Rent Checks'?
subtitle: An author's online financial pitch is based upon existing information, but experts caution that it is no "hidden pot of money."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Americans can collect "Federal Rent Checks" by using Public Law 92-313 to their benefit.

title: Was a 'My Little Pony' Animator Arrested for Possession of Child Pornography Part of '#PedoGate'?
subtitle: An animator for the children's cartoon has been sentenced to prison for possessing child pornography, but the case is not part of a "#PedoGate" conspiracy.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: An animator for the "My Little Pony" cartoon series was arrested for child pornography, proving that the PedoGate conspiracy is real.

title: Did the Supreme Court Rule in 1943 That No One Can Be Forced to Participate in Patriotic Rituals?
subtitle: The Supreme Court's 1943 ruling applied to school board officials and other government entities, not private sector enterprises such as the NFL.
author: David Emery
statement: In 1943 the Supreme Court ruled that no one can be forced to participate in patriotic rituals such as the Pledge of Allegiance and the national anthem, so calling for NFL players to be fired for "taking a knee" in protest amounts to calling for the law to be broken.

title: Does This Meme Accurately Show 'Trump and Obama by the Numbers'?
subtitle: Donald Trump, Jr. shared a doctored graphic which falsely showed his father with a higher job approval rating than his predecessor, Barack Obama.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A "Trump and Obama by the Numbers" meme recounts accurate statistics about their job performances.

title: Was the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department Scrutinized After Posting a Photograph of a Deputy Praying?
subtitle: A small number of people complained after the department posted a photograph of a deputy praying, but the vast majority of responses were positive.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department was put under scrutiny for posting a photograph of a deputy praying before his shift.

title: Was a 'Pedophiles Are People Too' Notice Posted Near an Oregon School?
subtitle: A sign reading "Pedophiles are People Too" was briefly pinned to a telephone pole near a school in Oregon, but this poster was likely created as part of a troll campaign.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A pedophilia group put up a sign reading "Pedophiles are People Too" near a school in Oregon.

title: Did Congressman Jason Lewis Call for a Dress Code for American Women?
subtitle: In his career as a radio host, Lewis said he should be able to call women "sluts" but did not demand they be dressed demurely and "fully-clothed."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Rep. Jason Lewis (R-Minnesota) called for women to have a "demure and fully-covered" dress code.

title: Did the Trump 2020 Campaign Order Flags and Banners Made in China?
subtitle: Bernie Sanders claimed that the president and his re-election campaign are responsible for increased production of Chinese-made "Trump 2020" merchandise.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Trump re-election campaign is responsible for a surge in orders of "Trump 2020" flags and banners produced in Chinese factories, just before the imposition of U.S. tariffs.

title: Did the #WalkAway Campaign Use Stock Photographs for People It Claimed Left the Democratic Party?
subtitle: The founder of a viral political campaign claims memes featuring stock photo models instead of real people were not produced by the WalkAway Campaign.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The #WalkAway Campaign used ads featuring stock photograph models and claimed they were Democrats leaving the party.

title: Did President Trump Say Pedophiles Will Get the Death Penalty?
subtitle: In a 2012 tweet, Donald Trump called for a "fast trial, death penalty" for "perverts" who abduct children.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Trump has called for the death penalty for pedophiles.

title: Will All Freon-Based Air Conditioners Need to Be Replaced by 2020?
subtitle: Although the the production or import of a chemical used in Freon will be banned in the U.S. beginning in 2020, Freon-based A/C units will not have to be replaced right away.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Air conditioners that use the refrigerant Freon will have to be replaced by 2020.

title: Is San Francisco Registering 'Illegal Aliens' to Vote?
subtitle: Non-citizen residents of San Francisco who have children can now register to vote in local school board elections.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: San Francisco is registering "illegal aliens" to vote.

title: Is NASA Training a 17-Year-Old Girl to Be an Astronaut?
subtitle: Alyssa Carson's passion for space has fueled her desire to take part in a mission to Mars as an adult.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A 17-year-old girl named Alyssa Carson is being trained by NASA to become an astronaut.

title: Did President Trump Break Protocol in His Meeting with Queen Elizabeth?
subtitle: Criticism of the U.S. president's actions in the U.K. was largely based on cherry-picked images and misinformation about royal etiquette.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Donald Trump broke royal protocol by arriving late to meet Queen Elizabeth, failing to bow, and walking in front of her.

title: Did Donald Trump Say He Believes the UK Has 'Different Names'?
subtitle: President Trump made a comment during an interview with British media personality Piers Morgan suggesting he believes terms such as "U.K." and "England" are interchangeable.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: U.S. President Donald Trump told Prime Minister Theresa May he believes the terms "U.K.," "England" and "Great Britain" can be used interchangeably.

title: Were None of 154 Mass Shootings in 2018 Committed by a Black Man, Illegal Alien, or Woman?
subtitle: A hyperpartisan Facebook page gave readers an incomplete picture of mass shootings in America in 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Of the 154 mass shootings recorded in the U.S. in 2018 through 28 June, none of them were perpetrated by black men, undocumented immigrants, or women.

title: Did the Trump Administration Say Employers Can Fire Workers for Being Gay?
subtitle: A legal argument offered in a discrimination case by the Justice Department in 2017 disclaimed Title VII protections for sexual orientation but didn't change extant law.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: President Donald Trump's administration said that employers are allowed to fire workers if they are gay.

title: Police: 13-Year-Old Girl Was Beheaded After Seeing Her Grandmother Die
subtitle: A 13-year-old girl with special needs was beheaded because she saw her grandmother murdered in a cemetery, according to court testimony.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A 13-year-old girl was beheaded by an "illegal immigrant" in a crime "suppressed" by the mainstream news media.

title: Did President Trump Cancel Protections for Whales and Sea Turtles?
subtitle: A news web site got some facts right but gave an incomplete and misleading account of a June 2017 decision made by the federal agency responsible for fisheries.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In June 2017, President Donald Trump canceled federal protections for whales and sea turtles

title: Does Trump Donate All of His Presidential Salary, While Obama Donated None?
subtitle: An Internet meme made misleading comparisons between presidential donations and the sizes of the first ladies' staffs, calling the Trumps "givers" and the Obamas "takers."
author: David Emery
statement: Donald Trump donates his entire presidential salary and Melania Trump has a White House staff of only four, while President Obama donated nothing and First Lady Michelle Obama had a staff of 23.

title: Did Facebook Flag the Declaration of Independence as Hate Speech?
subtitle: A phrase contained in a excerpt from one of America's founding documents triggered the social network's acceptable content filtering.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Facebook (or its algorithms) flagged the Declaration of Independence as "hate speech" in July 2018.

title: Are Detained Immigrant Children Required to Recite the Pledge of Allegiance?
subtitle: Critics say the requirement forces migrant children to pledge allegiance to a country that separated them from their families.
author: David Emery
statement: Immigrant children separated from their parents and held in detention centers around the country are required in some cases to recite the Pledge of Allegiance daily.

title: Silent Fireworks
subtitle: "Silent fireworks" shows are a thing, but they don't employ a newly-invented form of noise-suppressing pyrotechnics.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Several cities have started to use "silent fireworks" in order to make the shows more enjoyable for children, pets, and people with PTSD.

title: Was Joe Biden Refused Service at 'Crumb and Get It' in 2012?
subtitle: A Virginia cookie shop declined to host a media event with the former U.S. vice president during a campaign stop in 2012.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Vice President Joe Biden was refused service at the Crumb and Get It cookie shop in 2012.

title: Will Canadians' Cell Phones Now Be Searched at the U.S. Border?
subtitle: In late June 2018, a web site resurrected months-old news about potential cellphone searches by U.S. border officials.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: U.S. border officials are now searching the cellphones of Canadian citizens entering the United States.

title: Did News Media Incorrectly Report That Border Agents Separated a Girl from Her Mother?
subtitle: Mainstream news organizations were criticized for illustrating articles about family separation at the border with a photograph of a crying child who was in fact never separated from her mother.
author: David Emery
statement: News media outlets misrepresented a photograph of a two-year-old migrant girl whose mother was arrested at the U.S-Mexico border as depicting an instance of family separation.

title: Can Amputees Take Their Limbs Home?
subtitle: A Reddit user's account of his post-amputation experience of bringing home his leg and making tacos out of it is decidedly uncommon, but at least part of his story is not unheard of.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: People who undergo amputations can sign paperwork allowing them to take the removed limbs home after the procedure.

title: Did a VA Hospital Replace Military Flags with a Pride Flag?
subtitle: An Indiana veterans facility temporarily removed military flags to fly a rainbow flag, an action some social media users mistook for a permanent change.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A VA hospital removed military flags in order to fly a LGBTQ pride flag.

title: What Does the Effect of a Bullet Fired From an AR-15 Look Like?
subtitle: Photographs shared widely on social media offer an incomplete explanation of the kinds of damage done by gunshots.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A large circle marked on a protester's poster is an accurate reflection of the size of the hole created by an AR-15 round.

title: Is the Trump Administration Putting Immigrant Children in 'Tent Cities'?
subtitle: Multiple news outlets reported that the Department of Health and Human Services is planning tent cities to accommodate a recent influx of immigrant children - but the practice is not new.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Trump administration is building "tent cities" to house minor immigrants.

title: Is The NFL's History of Free Speech Issues Accurately Portrayed in This List?
subtitle: A list purportedly demonstrating the National Football League's hypocrisy regarding free expression deals largely with genuine incidents - but whether its entries are "free speech" issues is debatable, and some of its details are inaccurate.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A list accurately portrays the NFL's history on free speech issues.

title: Are Teenagers Using Adhesives to Avoid Resorting to Condoms?
subtitle: A Hong Kong company garnered global headlines with its "Jiftip" product, but it's not clear who's actually buying it.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 2017 and 2018, teenage boys widely purchased and used a urethra-covering adhesive band called the Jiftip.

title: Was a Massive Pedophile Ring with '70,000 Elite Members' Busted by Police?
subtitle: A disreputable web site with a penchant for pedophilia-related clickbait deceptively reported a years-old story as current news.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A recent international investigation resulted in the shutting down of an online pedophilia forum with some 70,000 members worldwide.

title: Obama and the FBI - Connect the Dots
subtitle: A photograph of President Obama with current and future FBI directors is neither ominous nor revealing.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A revealing photograph shows President Obama with current and future FBI directors.

title: Did President Trump Order Detained Immigrants to Wear Yellow Bracelets?
subtitle: Some reports have held that President Trump has "just begun" an immigration-related policy which actually started in 2005.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 2018, President Donald Trump began a policy of forcing detained immigrants scheduled for criminal prosecution to wear identifying wristbands and yellow bracelets.

title: Is This a Photograph of a Children's Concentration Camp in the U.S.?
subtitle: Debate continues over how temporary holding facility and processing centers for undocumented migrant children should  be described.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph shows a 'kids' concentration camp' in the U.S.

title: Did Christopher Columbus Seize, Sell, and Export Sex Slaves?
subtitle: A Facebook meme accurately quoted from a letter written by Columbus himself.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Christopher Columbus sold sex slaves - some as young as nine years old.

title: Which Has Killed More People in 2018: School Shootings or Military Service?
subtitle: The answer to this question depends upon the criteria used for inclusion.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: So far in 2018, the number of U.S. students killed in school shootings is greater than the number of U.S. military personnel who have been killed on active duty.

title: Did Trump Echo Hitler by Calling Undocumented Immigrants 'Animals'?
subtitle: A meme summarized Nazi beliefs about Jewish people but drew a less accurate link to President Trump's comments about immigrants.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Donald Trump called undocumented immigrants "animals," just as Adolf Hitler called Jewish people "animals."

title: Will Louisiana Evict Nursing Home Patients Because Medicaid Ran Out?
subtitle: Although the state has passed an operating budget without evicting elderly people, Louisiana's fiscal woes continue.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Louisiana will evict elderly people from nursing homes because Medicaid funds ran out.

title: Did Colorado Democrats Pass a 'Gun Confiscation' Bill?
subtitle: H.B. 1436 would allow for gun confiscation, but only under very narrow circumstances and as a measure to prevent suicides and mass shootings.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In May 2018, the Colorado House of Representatives passed a "gun confiscation" bill.

title: Are These the Average Minimum Wages and Big Mac Prices in Three Countries?
subtitle: The "Fight for 15" labor movement uses the McDonald's signature burger to criticize its salary practices.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A meme circulating online shows the average minimum wages in France, Australia, and the U.S. as well as the average cost of a Big Mac in each country.

title: Was a Black Man Acquitted of a Crime - and Also Jailed for It?
subtitle: A viral video gets some details right about the case of Ramad Ahshad Chatman, but leaves out one crucial fact.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Ramad Chatman was given a jail sentence for a crime of which he was acquitted.

title: Were Two Young Black Men Lynched in Oklahoma Without Media Attention?
subtitle: Some have called the murder and dismemberment of two African-American men over a gun sale gone wrong a "modern lynching."
author: David Emery
statement: Two black men, Alize Ramon Smith and Jarron Keonte Moreland of Moore, Oklahoma, were lynched by four white people in April 2018, a crime that was largely ignored by the media.

title: Is Abraham Lincoln in the Wrestling Hall of Fame?
subtitle: A popular meme contained a mixture of myth, rumor, and facts (as well as a ridiculous digitally edited image) about the legendary United States president.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Abraham Lincoln was an accomplished wrestler who was inducted into the Wrestling Hall of Fame with a near-perfect record.

title: Is This a Real Hand With Eight Fingers?
subtitle: A set of images purportedly show a rare congenital syndrome called "ulnar dimelia," also known as "mirror hand syndrome."
author: Dan Evon
statement: A set of images show a congenital anomaly that resulted in an a hand with eight fingers.

title: Did a Virginia Newspaper Run a KKK Ad on the Front Page?
subtitle: The Westmoreland News published a photograph of a KKK recruitment flyer, a decision that was criticized as providing free advertising for the Klan.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The Westmoreland News ran a KKK ad on the front page of their newspaper in April 2018.

title: Did Hillary Clinton Smash Her Phone with a Hammer?
subtitle: According to FBI documents made public in 2016, one of Clinton's aides twice disposed of her old mobile devices by "breaking them in half or destroying them with a hammer."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Hillary Clinton used a hammer to smash her mobile phone during an FBI investigation.

title: Did Rep. Mike Kennedy Say 'Access to Hospitals' Was Responsible for Deaths?
subtitle: According to rumors, the Utah Republican says access to hospitals killed a million or more Americans a year - but is that true?
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Rep. Mike Kennedy claimed that access to hospitals kills at least a million Americans per year.

title: Was the Body of a Dead Pedophile Dumped in Front of Parliament?
subtitle: Some fake news sites just can't get over their obsessions with pederasty, likely because it makes for effective clickbait material.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The body of a notorious pedophile was found dumped on the doorstep of the British Parliament building.

title: 'I Live in Sweden': Facts About Swedish Society and Health Care
subtitle: A popular meme outlines the purported benefits of living in Sweden.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: We fact-check a popular meme outlining the purported benefits of living in Sweden.

title: Is 'Sleepy Eyes' an Anti-Semitic Slur?
subtitle: The descriptor was used by Nazi Germany as a way to "identify" those of Jewish descent, but researchers say context is key.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: President Donald Trump was using an anti-Semitic slur when he called NBC host Chuck Todd "sleepy eyes."

title: Six 'Facts' About Healthcare in Japan
subtitle: We fact-check a series of claims about Japan's healthcare and medical insurance system.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A meme presents accurately describes Japan's healthcare and health insurance system.

title: Did Jane Goodall Compare Donald Trump's Actions to Primate Dominance Behavior?
subtitle: A meme about United States President Donald Trump and French leader Emmanuel Macron possibly references an apocryphal quote by the famous anthropologist and primatologist.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Anthropologist Jane Goodall likened Donald Trump's actions to primates engaging in dominance behavior.

title: Can Rapists Sue for Child Custody, While Rape Victims Cannot Sue for Child Support?
subtitle: A meme's claims about rape, child custody, and child support oversimplified a very complicated legal scenario.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A rapist may sue a victim for custody of a child in 31 states, but in no states may victims seek child support from rapists.

title: Did Planned Parenthood Donate $30 Million to Democrats to Influence the Midterm Elections?
subtitle: Social media memes misleadingly conflated Planned Parenthood itself with a coalition of organizations and PACs.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Planned Parenthood is spending $30 million in taxpayer subsidies to influence the outcome of the 2018 midterm elections.

title: Did a Town Crier Announce the Royal Birth?
subtitle: Tony Appleton may look and sound like the royal town crier, but he is not officially affiliated with the royal family.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The royal family's official town crier announced the birth of Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge's third child.

title: Did YETI Brand Coolers Cut Ties with the NRA?
subtitle: A press release from NRA-ILA claimed the YETI brand no longer wished to do business with the organization, but the details are disputed.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: YETI told the NRA the brand no longer wishes to do business with the organization, demonstrating that YETI does not support the Second Amendment.

title: Does Mike Pence's Brother Make Engines for the Russian Military?
subtitle: The Vice President is rumored to have close ties with the Russian government via his brother, Ed Pence, a former executive at engine manufacturer Cummins Inc.
author: David Emery
statement: One of Vice President Mike Pence's older brothers, Ed Pence, is an executive at Cummins Inc., a company that manufactures engines for the Russian military and has also used lobbying firms connected with Paul Manafort, indicating that Mike Pence may have compromising ties to Russia.

title: Did Samuel Beckett Drive a Young André the Giant to School?
subtitle: A legend about the iconic wrestler has a significant grain of truth to it but has been embellished over the years.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Samuel Beckett used to drive a teenaged André the Giant to school when they lived in a small French village.

title: Did Armed Delaware Students Scare Off a School Shooter in 1973?
subtitle: A pro-gun rights meme gets some facts right, but it misrepresents the truth behind an old high school yearbook photograph.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A viral photograph shows an armed student and teacher scaring off a would-be mass shooter at a Delaware high school in 1973.

title: Did Pope Francis 'Request' Marriage Rights for Catholic Priests?
subtitle: News reports exaggerated the scope and significance of comments made by the pontiff.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In November 2017, Pope Francis called for the right to marry for Catholic priests.

title: Did President Trump Exempt His Daughter's Clothing Line from China Tariffs?
subtitle: Although President Trump's tariffs on China imports excluded clothing items such as the ones imported for Ivanka Trump's clothing line, her company was not specifically singled out for an exemption.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump exempted Ivanka Trump's clothing line from tariffs on Chinese imports.

title: Does the U.S. Have Millions More Registered Voters Than Eligible Adults?
subtitle: A persistent claim about widespread voter fraud is based on problematic tallies of registered and eligible voters.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The U.S. has several million more registered voters than eligible, voting-age adults.

title: Did a Newspaper Ad for the Ku Klux Klan Praise Donald Trump?
subtitle: A purported KKK recruitment flyer found in Alabama praised the policies of President Donald Trump.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: An ad for the Ku Klux Klan found in a 2018 newspaper praised the policies of President Donald Trump.

title: Did Indiana Gov. Eric Holcomb Sign a Law Mandating Women Disclose Abortions or Face Jail Time?
subtitle: Vague social media posts and news items led to confusion over a broad Indiana law addressing "abortion complications."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Indiana Gov. Eric Holcomb passed a law that will lead to jail time for women who fail to disclose abortions.

title: Did David Hogg Offer Contrasting Stances on the First and Second Amendments?
subtitle: The Parkland school shooting survivor opposes a requirement for clear backpacks, but he has also stated repeatedly that he supports the Second Amendment.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: David Hogg stated that he believes that the enforced use of clear backpacks in school constitutes a violation of students' First Amendment rights, but he favors the abolition of the Second Amendment.

title: Did a GOP Lawmaker Report a High School Student for Cursing Over Gun Safety?
subtitle: Rep. Mark Amodei did not notify Noah Christiansen's school, but he defended the staff member who did.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Rep. Mark Amodei reported high-school student Noah Christiansen to his school for cursing during a phone call concerning gun safety legislation.

title: Is 'Super' Antenna Octa Air a Legitimate Replacement for Cable?
subtitle: A suspicious advertisement used doctored photographs and exaggerated claims to promote a new "super" antenna called Octa Air.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A new "super" antenna called Octa Air is a legitimate replacement for cable that can provide customers with 100s of free HDTV channels.

title: Was a Student Suspended for Staying in Class During National Walkout Day?
subtitle: The reasons behind a high school student's suspension were misconstrued in a debate over a national gun violence walkout protest.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An Ohio high school student was suspended for not participating in a walkout protest over gun violence.

title: Did Obama's Justice Department Force the FBI to Delete 500,000 Fugitives from a Background Check Database?
subtitle: A Justice Department decision made under Obama and implemented under Trump has garnered bipartisan criticism for its effect on the national background check system.
author: David Emery
statement: A decision by the Justice Department under the Obama administration forced the FBI to purge the names of 500,000 fugitives from justice from the background check database for firearms purchases.

title: Did a High School Principal Target a Pro-Gun Rights Student During a Protest for Gun Control?
subtitle: New Prague High School in Minnesota says a pro-gun rights placard was removed from a protest because it violated policy, not for political reasons.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A high school principal in Minnesota singled out a pro-gun rights student during a pro-gun control protest and escorted him off campus.

title: Did Abraham Lincoln Order the Execution of 38 Dakota Fighters?
subtitle: After a violent Native American uprising in 1862, President Lincoln signed off on 39 executions but also prevented the deaths of 264 other Dakota combatants.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 1862, Abraham Lincoln ordered the execution by hanging of 38 Dakota Sioux fighters.

title: Did a Church of Lucifer Open in Colombia?
subtitle: The founder of a so-called "Church of Lucifer" launched in Quindío, Colombia in 2016 also claims to sell "pacts with the devil" for profit.
author: David Emery
statement: A so-called "Church of Lucifer" has opened in Colombia.

title: Did President Donald Trump End Public Access to 'Puppy Mill' Inspection Reports?
subtitle: A searchable database of inspection reports was temporarily removed from the United States Department of Agriculture's web site as part of a review connected to a lawsuit.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Trump administration blocked public access to USDA reports on safety and hygiene standards at facilities where animals are kept and bred.

title: Does the United States Have a Lower Death Rate From Mass Shootings Than European Countries?
subtitle: A pro-gun rights economist used questionable statistical methods to create a misleading impression.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Between 2009 and 2015, the United States had a lower mass shootings death rate than several European countries.

title: Is Amazon's Alexa Creepily Laughing for No Apparent Reason?
subtitle: In February 2018, Amazon Alexa owners began claiming that the devices were randomly broadcasting an unwanted "creepy laugh."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Amazon's Alexa randomly plays a "creepy laugh."

title: Did California's Governor Ban Teachers from Shooting Back at School Shooters?
subtitle: Several web sites mischaracterized an October 2017 California law preventing school personnel from carrying guns on campus.
author: David Emery
statement: Gov. Jerry Brown of California signed a bill that bans teachers from carrying firearms and shooting back at school shooters.

title: Are Some Instant Pot Cookers Having Meltdowns?
subtitle: Days after a customer's account spread on social media, the company warned about a product defect affecting specific models.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Some Instant Pot cookers are overheating and having meltdowns.

title: Did People 'Attack' the Father of a School Shooting Victim for Wearing a Donald Trump T-Shirt?
subtitle: A very small minority of Twitter users expressed a critical view of Andrew Pollack, but none appear to have addressed their comments directly to him.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A significant number of internet users 'attacked' Andrew Pollack, a man mourning the death of his daughter, on the basis of his support for Donald Trump.

title: Presidential Responses to School Shootings?
subtitle: A set of images showing President Barack Obama and President Donald Trump in the aftermath of different school shootings are real, but they do not necessarily tell the entire story.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A set of images show President Barack Obama and President Donald Trump in the aftermath of various school shootings.

title: What Were the Consequences of Legalizing Weed in Colorado?
subtitle: A newspaper editorial gets some facts right, and some wrong, in weighing up the consequences of Colorado's legalization of recreational marijuana.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: We fact-check a series of claims about the damage caused by Colorado's legalization of recreational cannabis.

title: Did Dwight Eisenhower Reject the Idea of 'Soviet-Style' Military Parades?
subtitle: A meme intended to undermine President Trump's call for a military parade quotes general-turned-president Dwight Eisenhower on the subject.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: President Eisenhower rejected the idea of military parades, saying they "would make us look weak."

title: Can Police Legally Rape Women in 35 States?
subtitle: A pair of articles about the legality of rape in police custody confused social media readers.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In 35 states, it's legal for police officers to have sex with unconsenting detainees.

title: Does the Dow Jones Do Worse Under Republican Presidents?
subtitle: A Facebook meme purporting to prove that the Dow suffers under Republican presidencies ignores key data.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The seven biggest one-day Dow Jones points drops took place during Republican presidencies, showing that Republicans are not "good for the economy."

title: Did Outback Steakhouse Kick Out a Policeman Because it is a 'Gun Free Zone'?
subtitle: An incident that generated outrage on social media does not reflect company policy, according to the restaurant chain.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Outback Steakhouse is a "gun free zone" and a police officer was ejected for carrying his service weapon.
