title: Do Amazon Employees Qualify for Food Stamps?
subtitle: Official statistics suggest that some of the online retail giant's workforce receive food stamps, but it only applies to about 12 percent of one state's employees.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Amazon employees "earn so little they qualify for food stamps."

title: Are Farmers Injecting Fruits and Vegetables with Oxytocin?
subtitle: Reports imply Indian farmers are using oxytocin to boost the size of their fruits or vegetables , but it is unclear how widespread the practice may be.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Farmers are injecting fruits and vegetables with the human hormone oxytocin to enhance their growth and appearance.

title: Did Donald Trump's 2018 Budget Proposal Cut Support for Disabled Veterans?
subtitle: The president's plan did call for changes that would have had a significant financial effect on some disabled veterans, but the policy has been abandoned.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: President Donald Trump's 2018 budget proposal calls for cuts in benefits to highly disabled veterans

title: Did ICE Deport a Michigan Doctor 40 Years After He Immigrated to the U.S.?
subtitle: The doctor, who is in ICE custody, was convicted of two misdemeanors as a teenager 26 years ago.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) detained and deported Polish doctor Lukasz Niec, 40 years after he emigrated to the United States as a young child.

title: Did the Chief Executive Officer of Nestlé Say Water Is Not a Human Right?
subtitle: The CEO of a multinational company that makes billions annually selling bottled water called the idea that human beings have a right to water "extreme."
author: David Emery
statement: Peter Brabeck-Letmathe, a former chairman and CEO of Nestlé, said that water is not a human right.

title: Are These Some Real Things Joe Arpaio Has Done?
subtitle: Among the heinous acts the controversial former Maricopa County sheriff was accused of in an Internet meme was burning a dog alive.
author: David Emery
statement: A widely shared social media post accurately lists reprehensible acts committed by former Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio.

title: Did Oprah Winfrey Say 'Old White People Have to Die'?
subtitle: Detractors have seized on Winfrey's 2013 comments about how to end racism in an effort to discredit the star.
author: David Emery
statement: Oprah Winfrey said that in order for the problem of racism to be solved, old white people have to die.

title: Did a Republican Group Post Anti-Trump Billboards in Minnesota?
subtitle: The billboards are real, but the so-called Republican group has an interesting donor behind it.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A group of Republicans in Minnesota erected billboards criticizing President Donald Trump in late 2017.

title: How Have the Net Worths of Presidents Changed?
subtitle: An image comparing changes in the financial status of former and current United States presidents is not particularly revealing.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An image contrasts changes in the financial status of former and current U.S. presidents.

title: The Remarkable Sabrina Pasterski
subtitle: A viral meme about a Harvard University graduate student gets most (but not all) of the facts right.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Four claims document remarkable characteristics about Harvard University graduate student Sabrina Pasterski.

title: Did UPS Lose a Family's $846,000 Inheritance, Then Refund the $32 Shipping Fee?
subtitle: The story about the United Parcel Service losing an inheritance check has been sensationalized for outrage clicks.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: UPS lost a family's $846,000 inheritance check but would only refund them the $32 shipping fee.

title: Did Rosie O'Donnell Offer Bribes to Senators on Twitter?
subtitle: The comedian "offered" two million dollars each to two Republican senators if they voted no on the GOP tax bill, but attendant bribery charges would be unlikely.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Rosie O'Donnell bribed two senators to vote "no" on the GOP tax bill via Twitter.

title: Did 'Antifa' Pour Concrete on Railroad Tracks, Causing an Amtrak Train to Derail?
subtitle: Activist groups have targeted tracks in the area, but there is no evidence that anti-fascists are responsible for the train derailment south of Seattle.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: "Antifa" admitted to pouring concrete on train tracks causing an Amtrak train to derail.

title: Did President Donald Trump Host the NRA on the Anniversary of the Sandy Hook Massacre?
subtitle: Progressive blogs reported that the White House hosted the National Rifle Association on the anniversary of a mass shooting.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Donald Trump hosted the National Rifle Association at the White House on the anniversary of the Sandy Hook massacre.

title: Did One of Roy Moore's Accusers 'Forge' Yearbook Evidence Against Him?
subtitle: Roy Moore accuser Beverly Young Nelson annotated Moore's 1977 signature and inscription in her high school yearbook, but she didn't "forge" his writing.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Roy Moore accuser Beverly Young Nelson "forged" Moore's signature and inscription in her high school yearbook.

title: Answering Your Questions About the 2017 Tax Bill
subtitle: What's true and what's false about the 2017 tax bill and its rumored provisions.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: We investigate an assortment of claims about the 2017 tax bill and its provisions.

title: Did Roy Moore Author a Textbook That Argued Women Shouldn't Hold Political Office?
subtitle: Roy Moore contributed to a study course which argued that women should not hold political office, but he did not personally author the offending chapter.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Former Alabama judge Roy Moore authored a chapter in a 2011 textbook arguing that women should not hold political office

title: Did the Drug Enforcement Administration Legalize Synthetic Marijuana While Keeping 'the Real Thing' Illegal?
subtitle: Bioidentical but synthetic THC has been approved for medical use since 1985, but it was only recently approved in a liquid formulation.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The DEA recently classified synthetic marijuana as a legally-obtainable Schedule II drug while continuing to list plant-based marijuana as a Schedule I drug with “no currently accepted medical use.”

title: Can You Access Emergency Services by Pressing an iPhone's Lock Button Five Times?
subtitle: Users of the iPhones running iOS 11 can make use of the feature but should take some precautions.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: iPhone users can access emergency services simply by tapping the Lock button of their device five times.

title: Did President Trump Reverse an Insecticide Ban After Receiving $1 Million from Dow Chemicals?
subtitle: The Trump administration reversed a previous decision to ban the use of a common insecticide, and it did receive money from that chemical's manufacturer.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Chlorpyrifos, an insecticide with alleged origins in Nazi Germany, was set to be banned by the EPA over health and environmental safety concerns; but President Trump reversed this decision after Dow Chemicals, a manufacturer of the chemical, donated one million dollars to his inauguration fund.

title: Did Rep. Joe Barton Proclaim 'Wind Is a Finite Resource'?
subtitle: Texas Rep. Joe Barton supposedly once said that 'wind is a finite resource and harnessing it would slow the winds down, which would cause the temperature to go up.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Rep. Joe Barton said "wind is a finite resource and harnessing it would slow the winds down, which would cause the temperature to go up."

title: Is Shenandoah National Park Selling Trump Wines?
subtitle: A private company that runs concessions at Shenandoah National Park in Virginia has been selling the President's branded wines.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The U.S. National Park Service is selling Trump-branded wines at Shenandoah National Park in Virginia.

title: Did ISIS Call for the Assassination of Barron Trump?
subtitle: A message on the Telegram app from an "ISIS supporter" used a hashtag translated to "handle the son of the mule of America."
author: Dan Evon
statement: ISIS called for the assassination of Barron Trump in November 2017.

title: Would the Republican Tax Plan Count Graduate Tuition Waivers as Taxable Income?
subtitle: The House of Representatives version would, the Senate version would not.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Republican tax reform plan would increase the tax burden on graduate students by counting waived tuition as personal income.

title: Was a Woman Attacked on Camera for Wearing a 'Make America Great Again' Hat in Hollywood?
subtitle: YouTube personality Blaire White initiated a confrontation at an anti-Trump protest, according to police.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A woman was attacked in Hollywood because she was wearing a pro-Donald Trump hat.

title: President Trump Abruptly Shuts Down Dogs for Wounded Warriors Program?
subtitle: Sketchy articles about the Warrior Canine Connection and a canceled contract with Walter Reed Medical Center omitted key details..
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Trump abruptly closed the Dogs for Wounded Warriors program.

title: Sutherland Springs Shooting Rumors, Hoaxes, and Conspiracy Theories
subtitle: A mass shooting at a Texas church on 5 November 2017 led to an avalanche of false information.
author: Brooke Binkowski
statement: We investigated a number of hoaxes, rumors, and conspiracy theories associated with a mass shooting in Sutherland Springs, Texas on 5 November 2017.

title: Did Papa John's Withdraw Their NFL Advertising Over Anthem Protests?
subtitle: The pizza chain will be removing the NFL logo and the label of "official sponsor" from their television commercials, but they have not stopped advertising with the league.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: As of November 2017, Pizza chain Papa John's had pulled their advertising from the National Football League.

title: Papa John's John Schnatter vs. Little Caesar's Mike Ilitch
subtitle: A meme comparing the founders of Papa John's (John Schnatter) and Little Caesar's (Mike Ilitch) pizza chains contains a mixture of facts and factoids.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A meme contains accurate information about the founders of Papa John's (John Schnatter) and Little Caesar's (Mike Ilitch) respectively.

title: Did Mexico Sign a Major Trade Deal With Argentina to Retaliate Against Trump's Border Wall Plans?
subtitle: Mexico is in trade talks with Argentina, but no deal has been finalized; the cost to American farmers would likely be lower than claimed.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In retaliation for Donald Trump's border wall plan, Mexico will soon shift all its imports of corn, rice, soy, and wheat from the United States to Argentina.

title: Was an Attack on United States Soldiers in Niger a Debacle 'Worse than Benghazi'?
subtitle: Given the paucity of information available two weeks after an ambush by militants on U.S. troops in Niger in October 2017, comparisons to Benghazi are perhaps a bit premature.
author: David Emery
statement: The killing of four U.S. soldiers in an October 2017 ambush by Islamic militants in Niger was far worse a debacle than the 2012 attack on U.S. diplomatic facilities in Benghazi.

title: Was a Transgender Woman Convicted of Sexually Assaulting a Young Girl in a Bathroom?
subtitle: A spate of blog posts attempted to link the rape of a 10-year-old girl in her home to laws allowing transgender people to use bathrooms that correspond to their identity.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A transgender woman raped a young girl in a women's bathroom because bills were passed allowing transgender people to use bathrooms which correspond with their gender.

title: Did California Governor Sign a Law Allowing Felons to Vote While in Prison?
subtitle: In September 2016, Jerry Brown did sign a law allowing some -- but not all -- convicted felons to vote while still behind bars.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: California Governor Jerry Brown signed a law allowing convicted felons to vote while still in prison.

title: Did a Drag Queen in a 'Demonic' Outfit Read a Sexually Explicit Book to Children at a Public Library?
subtitle: Right-wing web sites used alarmist language and false claims to describe a reading event at a California library.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In October 2017, a "demonic" drag queen read a "sexually explicit" book to children at a Long Beach public library named after Michelle Obama.

title: Is Trump Spending More Taxpayer Dollars on Personal Travel than Obama Did?
subtitle: Despite preliminary indications that the Trump family's government-paid travel expenses are higher than the Obamas', Internet rumors exaggerate the disparity.
author: David Emery
statement: After only nine months in office, President Trump and family had already spent $147 million on personal travel, amounting to one-and-a-half times as much as President Obama and family spent in the eight years of the latter's presidency.

title: Did Sprinklers Save a House from a Massive Wildfire?
subtitle: A photograph showing a home with a green lawn surrounded by charred land is real, but the back story accompanying it is incomplete.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image shows a house that was saved from a fire by sprinklers.

title: Las Vegas Shooting Rumors, Hoaxes, and Conspiracy Theories
subtitle: The deadliest mass shooting in modern American history has led to a cacophony of rumors, hoaxes, and conspiracy theories.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: We investigated a number of hoaxes, rumors, and conspiracy theories associated with a mass shooting on the Las Vegas strip on 1 October 2017.

title: Did Trump Administration Refuse Puerto Rico's Request to Allow Food Stamps to be Used for Hot Meals?
subtitle: The Department of Agriculture agreed to waive the usual "hot food" ban for food stamps and denies rejecting an earlier waiver request.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Department of Agriculture rejected a request by Puerto Rico that Nutrition Assistance Program rules be waived so that food stamps recipients could use EBT cards to purchase hot food.

title: Is This Viral List of U.S. Government Emergency Aid Sent to Puerto Rico Accurate?
subtitle: Some social media posts defending the Trump administration's relief efforts in Puerto Rico following Hurricane Maria strayed into fictional territory.
author: David Emery
statement: A social media meme accurately lists U.S. government assets deployed by President Trump to aid Puerto Ricans in the aftermath of Hurricane Maria.

title: Did the NFL Give Donald Trump a Lifetime Ban After a Disastrous Lawsuit?
subtitle: A viral meme got some facts right about an infamous 1980s lawsuit involving Donald Trump's football team but missed the mark with others.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The NFL gave Donald Trump a "lifetime ban" after he was involved in a disastrous lawsuit against the league.

title: Did a Cheesecake Factory Customer Receive Misleading 'Tip Suggestions' on His Receipt?
subtitle: A viral Facebook post shows an authentic credit card receipt for a Cheesecake Factory order with misleading and exaggerated tip suggestions, but the discrepancy was caused by an error.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2017, a Cheesecake Factory customer in California received a check that presented misleading and exaggerated tip suggestions.

title: Did Donald Trump Bankrupt a Golf Course, Leaving Puerto Rico with $33 Million in Debt?
subtitle: A viral string of tweets got some facts right about a failed business venture involving a Trump company, but it also left out some important context.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Donald Trump "bankrupted" a golf course in Puerto Rico, leaving taxpayers there on the hook for $33 million worth of debt.

title: Did the Iowa Hawkeyes Build a Children's Hospital Next to Their Stadium?
subtitle: A Facebook post got some facts right about a popular tradition by the University of Iowa's football team.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Iowa Hawkeyes football team built a children's hospital next to their stadium and started a tradition of waving at its patients during home games.

title: Are NFL Players Required to Stand on the Field During the National Anthem?
subtitle: Confusing claims about whether the NFL's rulebook or game operations manual specifically requires players to stand on the sideline during the pre-game playing of the U.S. national anthem.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The NFL's rulebook contains a regulation specifically requiring players to stand on the sideline during the pre-game playing of the U.S. national anthem.

title: Did a Harvard Study Prove That Apple Slows Down iPhones to Boost Sales of New Ones?
subtitle: Some iOS upgrades have slowed down the processor speed of some older iPhone models, but not for the conspiratorial purpose of driving new iPhone sales.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A Harvard study proved that Apple purposely slows down its older model iPhones to coincide with device releases and to boost sales of new models.

title: Are Radioactive 'Diamond Batteries' a Real Thing?
subtitle: While the science underpinning the concept is valid, its application remains wholly theoretical at this point.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Man-made, radioactive “diamond batteries” are capable of providing thousands of years of energy without a charge.

title: 9 'Facts' About Slavery They Don't Want You to Know
subtitle: A widely circulated list of historical "facts" about slavery dwells on the participation of non-whites as owners and traders of slaves in America.
author: David Emery
statement: A circulating list of nine historical "facts" about slavery accurately details the participation of non-whites in slave ownership and trade in America.

title: Spacesuit Envy
subtitle: Did NASA have to relabel the size chart for a condom-like urination contraption used in space suits because astronauts refused to choose the 'small' size?
author: Dan Evon
statement: NASA had to relabel the size chart used for a condom-like urination contraption built into the Maximum Absorbency Garment space suit system because astronauts refused to choose the "small" size.

title: Flashlight Apps Harbor Data-Stealing Malware?
subtitle: Flashlight apps could harbor furtive code to steal your personal data and send it to foreign cybercriminals, but so could any phone app.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Flashlight apps harbor furtive code to steal your personal data and send it to foreign cybercriminals.

title: Muslim-American Medical Demographics
subtitle: A claim that Muslim-Americans make up 1% of the U.S. population is accurate, but statistic dealing with mass shootings and medical training are problematic to verify.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Muslims comprise 1% of the population, 0.5% of mass shooters, and 10% of doctors in the U.S.

title: Did Pizza Hut Pressure Workers Evacuating From Irma's Path to Stay at Work?
subtitle: The company said a franchise manager "elected to add a few things" to a set of company recommendations.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Pizza Hut pressured employees in Florida to return to work "within 72 hours" if they evacuated because of tropical storm Irma.

title: Hurricane Irma Rumor FAQ
subtitle: Hurricane Irma has prompted the showering of social media with rumors, astonishing photographs, and other questionable claims.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: An assortment of rumors associated with Hurricane Irma in September 2017.

title: 'Violent Mob' Forced Police to Shut Down a 'Patriot Picnic' at Chicano Park?
subtitle: No violence erupted at San Diego's landmark park honoring the city's Latino heritage, although police told far-right activists to leave the premises after tensions with a rival group escalated.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Pro-Donald Trump activists were accosted by a "violent mob" while eating pizza at a Chicano Park.

title: Does Equifax's Credit Monitoring Service Bar Users From Joining a Class-Action Suit Against Them?
subtitle: After a massive data breach, the terms of service for an Equifax product spawned allegations that the company was trying to curb potential legal action.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: If you sign up for Equifax's credit-monitoring service, you cannot join any class-action lawsuit against the company.

title: Did the Red Cross Prevent 400 Hamburgers from Getting to Harvey Victims?
subtitle: A vague, viral post claiming that Red Cross volunteers refused to serve hamburgers was reprinted by various web sites without verification.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Red Cross blocked the distribution of 400 hamburgers to Harvey evacuees in Texas.

title: Red Cross Served 'Unacceptable' Meals to Louisiana Flood Victims?
subtitle: Viral photographs showed meager, unappetizing meals served to flood victims in Louisiana by the American Red Cross in 2016. They weren't the only images of Red Cross rations out there, however.
author: David Emery
statement: The Red Cross gave out meager and unappetizing meals to Louisiana flood victims.

title: Donald Trump Donated Play-Doh, Other Items to Louisiana Flood Victims?
subtitle: Presidential candidate Donald Trump was criticized for donating Play-Doh to flood victims in need of food and water, but that wasn't the only item among his donations.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump donated Play-Doh brand modeling clay to Louisiana flood victims.

title: Imminent Changes Introduced to Texas Insurance Law in the Midst of Harvey?
subtitle: Viral posts on social media largely accurately describe a change to Texas state law about hurricane insurance - but they lack important context.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: On 1 September 2017, a new law will come into force in Texas, making it harder for consumers to get paid for property insurance claims related to weather.

title: Did Congress 'Quietly' Pass a Bill Allowing Warrantless Searches of Homes?
subtitle: Congress passed a bill authorizing a transit safety committee that contained language one representative considered too broad and unconstitutional.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Congress "quietly" passed legislation allowing authorities to raid private property with no warrant.

title: Was Joel Osteen's Houston 'Megachurch' Affected By Hurricane Harvey?
subtitle: The evangelist was criticized on social media for not opening Lakewood Church to help people fleeing the storm.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Joel Osteen's Lakewood Church in Houston is "inaccessible" because of flooding caused by Hurricane Harvey.

title: Why Are NFL Players on the Sidelines for the National Anthem?
subtitle: For much of the NFL's history, players weren't present on the field during the playing of "The Star-Spangled Banner."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: NFL players did not stand for the national anthem until the Defense Dept. started paying the league to stage patriotic displays in 2009.

title: Was a North Carolina Elections Official Indicted for 'Rigging' the 2016 Election?
subtitle: Richard Robert Rawling has been charged over his alleged actions in the March 2016 primaries, but they had no effect on any election outcome and there's no evidence he favored any one candidate or party.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In August 2017, Richard Robert Rawling was indicted for "skewing vote tallies" in favor of Donald Trump and other Republican candidates during the March 2016 primaries.

title: Did Oregon's Governor Sign a 'Gun Confiscation' Law?
subtitle: A right-wing web site accurately describes some parts of a gun control law, but also uses exaggerated and misleading language.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In August 2017, Oregon governor Kate Brown signed a "gun confiscation" law.

title: Was Robert E. Lee Opposed to Confederate Monuments?
subtitle: On the question of erecting Civil War monuments, the former Confederate general wrote that he thought it wiser "not to keep open the sores of war."
author: David Emery
statement: Between the end of the Civil War and his death, former Confederate General Robert E. Lee expressed opposition to the building of Confederate monuments.

title: The Post-Civil War Lives of Robert E. Lee and Jefferson Davis
subtitle: A Tumblr post mischaracterizes the two Confederate leaders' positions after the Civil War.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Both Robert E. Lee and Jefferson Davis disavowed the Confederacy after the Civil War.

title: Oklahoma University Forced to Remove a Cross from Their Chapel?
subtitle: East Central University in Oklahoma may ultimately have to remove Christian symbols from their non-denominational chapel, but that potential outcome is a long ways off.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: East Central University has been forced to remove a cross and other Christian symbols from their chapel.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Said That “Trump Could Be the Greatest President in History”?
subtitle: Kennedy did utter these words prior to Donald Trump's inauguration, but the omission of context changes his meaning significantly.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said that “Trump could be the greatest president in history.”

title: Did the CEO of Camping World Tell Trump Supporters Not to Shop at His Stores?
subtitle: Camping World CEO Marcus Lemonis didn't target President Trump's supporters as such, but he appears to have directed comments at supporters of  Trump's response to events in Charlottesville.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In August 2017, Camping World CEO Marcus Lemonis told supporters of President Donald Trump not to shop at his stores.

title: Spanish Woman Cut in Half in Fatal Elevator Accident?
subtitle: A web site posted an unclear translation of a news account about a grisly incident that killed a Spanish woman in a hospital shortly after she gave birth.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A woman in Sevilla, Spain, was "cut in half" in a fatal elevator accident in a hospital that occurred shortly after she gave birth.

title: Bomb-Sniffing Dogs Killed in Kuwait?
subtitle: A disturbing set of images purportedly shows a pile of dead bomb-sniffing dogs that were put down after their contract with a security company was cancelled.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Photographs shows dozens of bomb-sniffing dogs killed by a security company in Kuwait.

title: Answering Your Questions About the 2017 Total Solar Eclipse
subtitle: The 21 August 2017 celestial event will be viewable to millions in North America, but taking the proper precautions is important.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: We check an assortment of claims about the 2017 total solar eclipse over North America.

title: Has Iceland Eliminated Down Syndrome Through Abortion?
subtitle: A report by CBS News highlights a nearly 100 percent termination rate in the pregnancies of Icelandic women whose fetuses test positive for Down syndrome in genetic screenings, but some have mischaracterized this report.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Iceland has virtually removed the occurrence of Down syndrome from their population through abortion.

title: Did the Texas House of Representatives Pass a Law Requiring Women to Buy 'Rape Insurance'?
subtitle: An article regurgitated a slightly misleading characterization of a Texas bill to reduce health insurance coverage for abortions.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In August 2017, the Texas House of Representatives passed a bill that would force women to purchase "rape insurance."

title: Can Drinking Cocktails From a Copper Mug Cause Poisoning?
subtitle: News articles exaggerate the health risks associated with normal consumption of cocktails such as the popular Moscow mule.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Drinking cocktails from a copper mug can cause copper poisoning

title: Does Arlington National Cemetery's Honor Guard Follow These Strict Rules?
subtitle: A popular viral item describes the duties and obligations of honor guards at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: List describes the duties and obligations of honor guards at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

title: Is NASA Hiring Someone to Protect Earth from Aliens?
subtitle: NASA has announced a job opening for a planetary protection officer, but viral news reports take significant liberties when describing the nature of the job.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: NASA will hire someone (with a secret security clearance) to ensure alien life doesn't make its way to Earth.

title: Does a Meme Accurately Advise Sexual Assault Victims?
subtitle: A meme posted to Reddit made statements of mixed accuracy about the rights of victims of rape and sexual assault.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: An image accurately states the rights a rape or sexual assault victim universally has in the wake of an attack.

title: Does Cuba Have a Cancer Vaccine That Has Already Cured Thousands?
subtitle: While a treatment for lung cancer developed in Cuba has entered clinical trials in the United States, it is not a preventative tool, nor has it “cured” thousands of people - at least yet.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Researchers in Cuba have discovered a cancer vaccine that is already saving thousands of people.

title: Home Pregnancy Tests Detect Testicular Cancer?
subtitle: A home pregnancy kit can detect testicular cancer in some circumstances, but it's not a reliable diagnostic test.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A home pregnancy test can detect testicular cancer.

title: Scientists Discover a Drug That Regenerates Teeth?
subtitle: Research using a chemical that stimulates stem cells in degraded teeth has been tested in mice with promising results, but the research is in its infancy.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Scientists have found a drug that regenerates teeth, and it could leave dentists without work.

title: Social Security 'Fun Facts'
subtitle: In which we check into some "fun facts" about Social Security from a Facebook meme saying the government should stop "messing" with retirement benefits.
author: David Emery
statement: A short list of "fun facts" distributed on the Internet accurately describes the workings of the U.S. Social Security system.

title: The Price They Paid
subtitle: A popular essay outlines the fates of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, but many of its details are inaccurate.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An essay outlines the fates of the signers of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Japan to Dump Deadly Fukushima Waste into Pacific Ocean?
subtitle: The claim that Japan has announced plans to dump 920,000 tons of nuclear waste into the Pacific strays from the known facts.
author: David Emery
statement: Japan announced plans to dump 920,000 tons of nuclear waste from the Fukushima Nuclear Plant into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Did Nancy Pelosi Say Obamacare Must be Passed to 'Find Out What Is in It'?
subtitle: A much-reproduced quote from the former Speaker of the House about the passage of the Affordable Care Act is typically presented out of context.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said of the Affordable Care Act, in 2010: "We have to pass the bill so that you can find out what is in it."

title: Did Hillary Clinton Tell FBI's Mueller to Deliver Uranium to Russians in 2009 'Secret Tarmac Meeting'?
subtitle: Hyperpartisan web sites mischaracterized a State Department cable alerting the U.S. Embassy in Russia of a transfer of criminal evidence obtained in a sting operation.
author: David Emery
statement: Then-Secretary of State Clinton ordered then-FBI Director Robert Mueller to deliver highly enriched uranium to the Russians in a secret plane-side meeting in 2009.

title: Rand Paul Tweeted That Purpose of Second Amendment Is to Shoot at Tyrannical Government?
subtitle: A genuine tweet posted by the Kentucky senator was circulated out of context after lawmaker Steve Scalise was shot in Virginia.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Rand Paul tweeted that the Second Amendment wasn't designed to protect our right to shoot deer, but the government when it becomes tyrannical.

title: Dry Drowning
subtitle: An account of a 10-year-old boy's death explains dry drowning and its symptoms.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Account of a 10-year-old boy's death explains dry drowning and its symptoms.

title: Did Uber Increase its Prices in London After a Terror Attack?
subtitle: Prices surged in the aftermath of the attack, but this increase was automatic and later suspended by Uber.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Uber increased its prices in parts of London around the time of a terror attack in June 2017

title: Do 'Fidget Spinners' Contain Deadly Amounts of Lead?
subtitle: A single small independent study stating that unusual amounts of lead were found in a few fidget spinners has been twisted into a fear-mongering report.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An official report has confirmed that fidget spinners contain a deadly amount of lead.

title: Did Cory Booker 'Defend' Jared Kushner After Receiving Donations From Him?
subtitle: Some commentators have drawn a link between Kushner's contributions and the New Jersey Senator's stance on removing Kushner's security clearance.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Cory Booker "defended" Jared Kushner on CNN, after receiving campaign contributions from him.

title: Did Rep. Darrell Issa 'Hide' on a Rooftop to Avoid Protesters?
subtitle: The Republican from California says he was simply taking pictures, but his political opponent says he was avoiding constituents.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Rep. Darrell Issa "hid" on the roof of his California office to avoid protesters.

title: Was an 11-Year-Old Girl Forced to Marry Her Rapist in Florida?
subtitle: Claims about an 11-year-old girl forced to marry a man who raped her appear to be true, but they were presented in a misleading fashion on social media.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: An 11-year-old Florida girl was depicted in a shocking photograph and forced to marry a much older man who raped her.

title: The Origins of Memorial Day
subtitle: One legend associated with the ocreation of Memorial Day holds that it was started by former slaves to honor Union war dead.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Memorial Day began with a May 1865 ceremony held by former slaves to honor Union war dead.

title: Everything Donald Trump Has Accomplished in Just Four Months?
subtitle: We looked into the accuracy of a viral list touting President Trump's accomplishments during his first four months in office.
author: David Emery
statement: An online graphic accurately details President Trump's notable accomplishments during his first four months in office.

title: Did the 'Doomsday' Seed Vault Flood Due to Global Warming?
subtitle: Although melting permafrost did cause flooding in the access tunnel to the vault, the vault itself was not breached and the seeds were not threatened or harmed.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, built to maintain Earth's botanical genetic diversity in the face of future calamities, flooded due to melting permafrost.

title: Can Ancestry.com Take Ownership of Your DNA Data?
subtitle: An experienced attorney's blog post has caused widespread concern.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Ancestry.com can retain the rights to your genetic information if you sign up for their DNA testing.

title: Prayers for Dakota
subtitle: A viral message requesting prayers for a young boy named Dakota is several months old and has frequently been shared without any context.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A young boy named Dakota was air lifted to the hospital after having a seizure.

title: Does Jeff Sessions Have Investments in the Private Prison Industry?
subtitle: A web site claimed that Sessions stood to gain from the recent reversal of an Obama-era policy on private prisons.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Attorney General Jeff Sessions has investments in the private prison industry.

title: Did President Obama Refuse to Turn the White House Blue to Honor Fallen Police?
subtitle: President Trump ordered the White House lit up in blue to commemorate Peace Officers Memorial Day 2017, prompting comparisons to former President Barack Obama.
author: David Emery
statement: President Trump ordered the White House bathed in blue light to honor fallen police officers, something President Obama "refused" to do.

title: Is Sean Spicer Wearing Mismatched Shoes?
subtitle: A photograph showing the White House press secretary wearing two different types of footwear is real, but the oddity appears to serve a medical purpose rather than an avant-garde fashion choice.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows Sean Spicer wearing one black shoe and one brown shoe.

title: Did the U.S. Government Purposely Poison 10,000 Americans During Prohibition?
subtitle: An Internet meme claims that government agencies tried to curb consumption of illegal liquor by adding poison.
author: David Emery
statement: In 1926, the federal government poisoned alcohol to curb consumption during Prohibition; by the time Prohibition ended in 1933, an estimated 10,000 people had died from this poisoning.

title: Did Bill Clinton Fire His FBI Director One Day Before Vince Foster Died?
subtitle: Conspiracy theorists find the timing of President Clinton's firing of William Sessions in 1993 "suspicious."
author: David Emery
statement: President Bill Clinton firing of FBI Director William Sessions was linked to Deputy White House Counsel Vince Foster's death a day later.

title: Joakim Noah Gives U.S. Soldiers the Finger, Refuses to Eat With Them?
subtitle: Joakim Noah skipped a dinner with the cadets while training at West Point, but the NBA star did not give U.S. soldiers the finger.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Joakim Noah gave the finger to US soldiers and refused to eat with them while training at West Point.

title: Is Joanna Gaines Quitting 'Fixer Upper'?
subtitle: Contrary to Internet rumor, the home improvement maven isn't quitting the HGTV show to start her own cosmetics company.
author: David Emery
statement: Joanna Gaines, who costars in the HGTV home improvement show "Fixer Upper" with her husband Chip, is leaving the show to start her own skincare line.

title: Is Sexual Assault a Pre-Existing Condition Under 'Trumpcare'?
subtitle: Critics of the American Health Care Act have accused Republicans of putting rape victims at risk of losing their health insurance.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Rape would be designated a pre-existing condition under the American Health Care Act.

title: Is 'TV Frog' a Legitimate Alternative to Cable?
subtitle: The product appears to be real, but it isn't, as described, a substitute for cable television.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A product called 'TV Frog' can replace your cable service.

title: Did Alabama 'Just Bring Back' School Segregation?
subtitle: A federal appeals court barred Gardendale from forming its own district, saying its motives for doing so were racial.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Alabama just brought back racial segregation in schools.

title: Did Ayn Rand Say 'The Question Isn't Who Is Going to Let Me; It's Who Is Going to Stop Me'?
subtitle: The quote, often attributed to Rand, is a paraphrase from one of her novels.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Ayn Rand said, "The question isn't who is going to let me; it's who is going to stop me."

title: Will Aaron Hernandez's Family Receive $15 Million from the NFL?
subtitle: Aaron Hernandez's conviction could be vacated under the obscure legal doctrine of
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Due to an obscure Massachusetts legal doctrine, Aaron Hernandez's death vacates his conviction and entitles his family to $15 million under the terms of his severed NFL contract.

title: More New England Patriots Players Attended White House Super Bowl Ceremony in 2015 than 2017?
subtitle: A side-by-side comparison of the number of New England Patriots players at a White House event in 2015 and 2017 is real, but misleading.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A set of photographs accurately depict the number of New England Patriots players in attendance at a White House ceremony in 2015 and 2017.

title: Sonic Drive-In Red Tray Keychain Promotion
subtitle: Sonic Drive-In promotions involving red tray keychains have been widely shared nationwide despite being local offers only.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Sonic Drive-In outlets are selling a $2 red tray keychain entitling the bearer to steep discounts on Route 44 beverages.

title: Did Women in Ancient Rome Drink Turpentine So Their Urine Would Smell Like Roses?
subtitle: A number of "true facts" web sites have stated that women in ancient and medieval times "sweetened" their chamber pots by drinking turpentine.
author: David Emery
statement: In ancient Rome, women would drink turpentine to make their urine smell sweet like roses.

title: Did Al Gore Predict Earth's Ice Caps Would Melt by 2014?
subtitle: In the late 2000s, the former U.S. Vice President sometimes inaccurately represented studies that predicted the timeline for an ice-free Arctic.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Al Gore predicted that Earth's “ice caps” would melt away by 2014.

title: Senator Jeff Flake: Solar Energy Can't Power Lights at Night?
subtitle: A comment made by Arizona senator Jeff Flake during a town hall meeting was reproduced without context to make him seem ignorant about the basics of solar power.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: At an Arizona town hall event, Sen. Jeff Flake told constituents "we can't rely on solar power because we can't tell people they will not have lights during the night."

title: State Dept. Employee Candace Claiborne Arrested on Treason Charges?
subtitle: Department of State employee Candace Claiborne was arrested and charged in connection with her improperly receiving gifts from Chinese agents.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Candace Claiborne, who worked for Barack Obama, has been arrested and charged with treason.

title: Did North Korea Threaten to 'Nuke' U.S. 'If Even a Single Bullet Is Fired'?
subtitle: The North Korean government apparently issued the warning, but it was not made in response to a U.S. naval strike force's being deployed to the region.
author: Bethania Palma

title: Reasons for Admission to Insane Asylums in the 19th Century
subtitle: A list purportedly documents the myriad reasons or symptoms behind patients' being admitted to insane asylums back in the 1800s.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A list  documents the myriad reasons why people were committed to insane asylums in the 19th century.

title: Elizabeth Warren Pays Female Staffers Less Than Their Male Counterparts?
subtitle: A report claiming Sen. Warren pays women less than men doesn't take into account the differing job titles of her staff.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: An analysis determined that Senator Elizabeth Warren pays her female staffers less than their male counterparts.

title: Is It Dangerous to Take a Bath During a Thunderstorm?
subtitle: While it is possible for one to be injured or killed by a lightning strike while bathing, such outcomes are rare.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: It is dangerous to take baths or shower during thunderstorms, and people have been injured or killed while doing so.

title: Did President Trump Open National Parks and Wildlife Refuges for Coal Mining?
subtitle: President Trump lifted a temporary moratorium on leasing federal lands for coal mining, but that activity was never completely shut down.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump opened National Parks and wildlife refugees to coal mining.

title: Did Obama's EPA Director Say the Clean Power Plan Would Have 'No Effect' on Carbon Emissions?
subtitle: Former U.S. Sen. Rick Santorum attributed the claim to former EPA head Gina McCarthy during a guest appearance on HBO's "Real Time with Bill Maher."
author: David Emery
statement: Former EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy said the Obama administration's Clean Power Plan would have little or no effect on carbon dioxide emissions.

title: Republicans Last Controlled U.S. Government in 1928 and Depression Followed?
subtitle: Popular post-election image holds that Republicans last controlled the White House and Congress in 1928, causing the Great Depression.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The last time Republicans controlled the presidency and Congress was in 1928, and the U.S. sunk into the Great Depression within a year.

title: Are Children Harming Themselves Because of a 'Fire Fairy' Game?
subtitle: A potentially dangerous set of instructions about "how to become a fairy" was circulated on social media site VK.com.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The "Fire Fairy Challenge" has tricked multiple children into harming themselves.

title: Did 14 Washington, D.C., Girls Go Missing Within a 24-Hour Period?
subtitle: Although there are still a number of missing teenagers in the D.C. area, local police refuted claims of a mass disappearance of girls there.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Fourteen teenaged girls went missing in Washington, D.C., within 24 hours.

title: Did Paul Ryan Say He Wants to Destroy Health Care?
subtitle: An old video capturing a gaffe from House Speaker Paul Ryan reappeared in March 2017.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Paul Ryan said that he would not stop until he destroyed health care in America.

title: Did President Trump Bestow $100 Million Upon Flint, Michigan?
subtitle: Partisans debate who deserves credit for the $100 million grant awarded by the EPA to Michigan for water infrastructure upgrades in Flint.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The Environmental Protection Agency awarded $100 million to Flint, Michigan, at the behest of President Trump.

title: Did Mike Huckabee's Son Kill a Dog?
subtitle: The son of former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee once killed a dog at Boy Scout camp, but the circumstances surrounding the act are unclear.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The son of former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee once killed a dog at Boy Scout camp.

title: Were There Irish Slaves in America, Too?
subtitle: Questionable sources maintain that the plight of so-called "Irish slaves" in early America was worse than that of African slaves. Historians beg to differ.
author: David Emery
statement: Early in America's history, white Irish slaves outnumbered black slaves and endured worse treatment at the hands of their masters.

title: Did President Trump Announce Plans to End the 'Meals on Wheels' Program?
subtitle: A budget blueprint released by the Trump administration would cut funding for a program that partially funds the Meals on Wheels program but would not end Meals on Wheels itself.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Donald Trump has announced budget cuts that would end the Meals on Wheels program.

title: Do Members of Congress Enjoy Free Health Care?
subtitle: According to memes, Congressional members and staffers are offered free, no-strings-attached health care, but there's more to the story.
author: Stephanie Larsen
statement: Congressional members receive free, high-quality health care.

title: Is Farm-Raised Tilapia from China Dangerous to Eat?
subtitle: Is the consumption of farm-raised tilapia and other fish imported from China a health risk?  Maybe, maybe not.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Eating farm-raised tilapia and other fish from China is dangerous.

title: Is it Illegal to Take Photographs of the Eiffel Tower at Night?
subtitle: As is often the case, a little bit of factual information is spun into something much more sensational.
author: Stephanie Larsen
statement: It is illegal to take photographs of the Eiffel Tower at night without explicit permission.

title: Were Iowa High School Students Forced to Apologize for Wearing Patriotic Colors?
subtitle: Conflicting reports about Iowa high school students supposedly forced to apologize for wearing red, white, and blue clothing at a basketball game led to social media arguments.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Iowa high school students were forced to apologize for wearing red, white, and blue at a sports game because immigrant students on the opposing team were offended.

title: Does H.R. 1313 Require Employees to Submit to Genetic Testing?
subtitle: The bill allows offering benefits for "voluntary" workplace programs that may include "health risk assessments" but does not enable mandatory genetic testing of employees.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: HR 1313 would allow employers to force workers to disclose their genetic information

title: Radioactive Canadian Salmon Tied to Fukushima Disaster?
subtitle: A single sockeye salmon found in a Canadian lake in 2015 did test positive for trace amounts of Fukushima radiation, but this is not a demonstrable health concern.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The first "radioactive salmon" attributed to the Fukushima nuclear disaster have been found in British Columbia, Canada, posing a risk to human health.

title: Does a Disney Cartoon Feature the Studio's First Gay Kiss?
subtitle: A meme urging a boycott of Disney after the studio featured a same-sex kiss in a cartoon does not display the actual moment of animated affection.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image shows two Disney animated characters sharing the studio's first same-sex kiss.

title: Do Corporations Routinely Buy 'Dead Peasant' Insurance?
subtitle: Large companies supposedly take out 'dead peasant' life insurance policies on low-level employees, to be paid out as executive bonuses.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Large corporations routinely take out "dead peasant" life insurance policies on low-level employees to be paid out as executive bonuses.

title: Is This a Red Blood Cell on the Tip of a Needle?
subtitle: A photograph purportedly showing a red blood cell on the tip of a needle is actually a composite of two (or more) images.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a red blood cell on the tip of a needle.

title: Did a Holocaust Museum Display a Poster Listing 'Early Warning Signs of Fascism'?
subtitle: The poster was not an exhibit but instead was at one point available in the gift shop of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, D.C. has a display listing off "early warning signs" of an encroaching fascist government.

title: Did Pope Francis Say It Was Better to Be an Atheist Than a Bad Catholic?
subtitle: Versions of a remark Pope Francis made about atheists and Catholics were misleadingly paraphrased.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Pope Francis said that it was 'better to be an atheist than a bad Catholic.'

title: Did 179 Children Go Missing  in Indiana in the First 47 Days of 2017?
subtitle: Many Facebook users misinterpreted a post about missing children in Indiana as suggestive of a wave of abductions occurring in that state.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In the first 45 days of 2017, 179 children went missing in the state of Indiana.

title: 'Media Silence' on $12B Reduction to the National Debt During Trump's First Month?
subtitle: Although President Trump cited accurate national debt figures in a  tweet, the newsworthiness of that information was questionable.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A lack of media attention regarding a $12 billion reduction to the national debt during President Trump's first month in office is attributable to biased news coverage.

title: Did House Republicans Pass a Rule Shielding Themselves from Prosecution?
subtitle: A new rule could make future investigations more difficult because it classifies public documents as the personal property of Congress members.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Republican U.S. representatives implemented a new rule that shields them from prosecution.

title: Starbucks and Same-Sex Marriage
subtitle: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz expressed the company's support for same-sex marriage but didn't tell opponents they weren't wanted as shareholders or customers.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz was confronted by a shareholder over the company's support for same-sex marriage.

title: Does A Proposed Tennessee Bill Classify Children Born from Artificial Insemination as “Illegitimate”?
subtitle: Though the bill's motivation is disputed, it would repeal a law that clarifies the legitimacy of children born from artificial insemination and the parental rights of their parents.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A bill introduced to the Tennessee General Assembly classifies children born from artificial insemination as illegitimate.

title: Did Congress Legalize Gun Purchases for People With Mental Impairments?
subtitle: More accurately, Congress passed the repeal of an Obama-era measure that would have made it easier to enforce existing restrictions on gun sales.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Congress passed a law that makes it legal for mentally impaired persons to purchase guns.

title: Is Burger King Distributing 'Adult Meals' and Toys for Valentine's Day?
subtitle: Confusing media coverage led many social media users to believe Burger King was distributing "adult meals" with grown-up "toys."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Burger King has introduced a new "adult meal" for Valentine's Day that includes a sex toy.

title: Were More People Deported Under the Obama Administration Than Any Other?
subtitle: A record number of people were "deported" from the U.S. during President Obama's tenure as president, due in large part to a change in definition.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A record number of people were deported from the U.S. during Barack Obama's tenure as President.

title: Does the Supreme Court Overturn 80 Percent of Ninth Circuit Court Decisions?
subtitle: Some confusing wording misleadingly suggested the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals' decisions almost never "stick."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Eighty percent of the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals' decisions are overturned by the Supreme Court.

title: Did Thousands of Muslims Leave the United States After Trump's Election?
subtitle: We found no evidence that President Trump's election has sparked a massive wave of self-deportation by Muslims.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Thousands of Muslims voluntarily left the United States after Donald Trump was elected president.

title: Did a Trump Supporter Kick a Pregnant Muslim Woman in the Stomach?
subtitle: A man was charged for kicking a Muslim woman in the stomach and killing her unborn twins, but he was not identified by police as a "Trump supporter."
author: Dan Evon
statement: A President Trump supporter kicked a Muslim woman in the stomach and killed her unborn twins.

title: National Prayer Breakfast Remarks: President Trump vs. President Obama
subtitle: An image comparing remarks made by President Trump and former President Obama at National Prayer Breakfasts used genuine quotes, but the implied claim was misleading.
author: Dan Evon
statement: An image macro accurately compares the remarks of President Trump and former President Obama at National Prayer Breakfasts.

title: Did 'The Simpsons' Predict Lady Gaga at Super Bowl LI?
subtitle: According to rumors, the animated series made several predictions that came true during the 2017 Super Bowl game.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The Simpsons correctly predicted various incidents that took place during Super Bowl LI.

title: Does a Photograph Depict a 5-Year-Old Syrian Girl Handcuffed at Dulles Airport?
subtitle: What's true and what's false about a widely shared and infrequently explained image taken of foreign visitors at Dulles Airport.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: An Image depicts a five-year-old Syrian girl in handcuffs at Dulles Airport.

title: Did a CAIR Leader Say That 'Muslims Are Above the Law'?
subtitle: A CAIR leader avowed that "if you're a true, practicing Muslim, you're above the law of the land" in 2013, but that statement has been taken out of context.
author: Dan Evon
statement: CAIR leader Mustafaa Carroll said that Muslims are above the law of the land and Sharia law supersedes the U.S. constitution

title: No Deadly Terrorist Attacks by People from Countries Included in Foreign Entry Restriction?
subtitle: A chart purportedly documents that no foreign national from any of seven countries included in a January 2017 executive order has killed any American citizens in the U.S. since 1975.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A chart documents that nationals from the seven countries included in President Trump's U.S. entry restriction have not killed any American citizens since 1975.

title: Did the Obama Administration Select the Countries Affected by President Trump's Immigration Order?
subtitle: President Trump's defenders maintained his January 2017 executive action on immigration and asylum targeted countries named by the Obama administration in 2015.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Trump's executive order limiting travel and immigration from certain countries was made possible under a bill signed into law by President Obama in 2015.

title: Did President Trump Order the Building of 'Concentration Camps'?
subtitle: An order calling for the construction of more immigrant detention facilities along the U.S.-Mexico border was equated with the establishment of "concentration camps."
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump has ordered the construction of concentration camps in the U.S.

title: Do Tom Bihn Bags Carry a Hidden Message About the President?
subtitle: Washing instruction tags on Tom Bihn bags once carried a hidden message  in French disparaging a president, but that was long before the Trump administration.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Washing instruction tags on Tom Bihn bags carry a hidden message in French disparaging the president.

title: Dan Rather Ends Retirement to 'Topple' Donald Trump?
subtitle: We can't say Rather ever "retired," as he has continued to work since leaving CBS News in 2004, and he has not said that his goal is to bring down Trump.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Dan Rather has come out of retirement as a newsman to "topple" the Trump administration?

title: President Obama Released $221 Million to the Palestinian Authority?
subtitle: The Associated Press reported that the outgoing president released aid to the Palestinian Authority that had been approved by Congress.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Obama defied Congress and "quietly" sent $221 million in aid to the Palestinian Authority.

title: Lawmakers Criminalize Peaceful Protest?
subtitle: Several state legislatures have proposed bills that would create harsher penalties for protesters, but none has yet been made into law.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Lawmakers are creating harsher criminal penalties for protesters

title: Should You Text 'Count Me' to 89800 to Support the Women's March?
subtitle: A third-party organization has urged Women's March participants to text "COUNT ME" to 89800 to be tallied, but the event's organizers have not endorsed the effort.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Women's March on Washington is tallying attendees by asking them to text "COUNT ME" to 89800.

title: Is Barack Obama More Self-Referential than Donald Trump?
subtitle: While Obama referred to himself more often in his farewell speech than Donald Trump did in his inaugural address, these speeches are not comparable.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Former president Barack Obama referred to himself 75 times during his farewell speech, compared to just 3 self-references by President Donald Trump in his inaugural address.

title: Clinton Foundation Dead as Contributions Dry Up?
subtitle: While the Clinton Global Initiative will be shutting down, the Foundation itself is still a going concern for the time being.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Clinton Foundation is shutting down due to lack of donations.

title: Did Donald Trump Remove the Terms 'LGBT' and 'Climate Change' from the White House Web Site?
subtitle: While the U.S. presidency transitioned from Barack Obama to Donald Trump, rumors swirled that the latter removed the terms "LGBT" and "climate change" from the White House web site.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump removed the terms "LGBT" and "climate change" from the White House web site.

title: Homeless Woman Holds Frozen Baby on Bench
subtitle: A homeless woman was found holding a dead baby at a Portland, Oregon bus stop, but this photograph does not show them.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a homeless woman outside in the cold holding a dead baby.

title: Did Russia Mint an 'In Trump We Trust' Coin?
subtitle: A commemorative 'In Trump We Trust' coin was created as a souvenir by a private Russian company, not minted as currency by the Russian government.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Russia minted "In Trump We Trust" coins ahead of the 45th U.S. president's inauguration.

title: Are Chinese People Selling Each Other Bags of Fresh Air?
subtitle: Chinese customers are buying bottles of fresh air from businesses that "farm" it where there is no air pollution.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Chinese people are selling each other bags of fresh air because of air pollution.

title: Is Paul Ryan Blocking All Calls and Faxes?
subtitle: According to social media rumors, House Speaker Paul Ryan is not allowing any calls or faxes to reach his offices.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Speaker Paul Ryan is blocking all incoming calls and faxes to his various offices.

title: Bystanders Do Nothing While Man Undergoing Seizure Gets His Pocket Picked at Walmart?
subtitle: A video shows a man convulsing on the floor at a Walmart store, with bystanders doing nothing to intervene when another man takes his wallet.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A video shows bystanders at Walmart doing nothing to intervene when a man experiencing a seizure is robbed of his wallet.

title: Did MLK Say 'Our Lives Begin to End the Day We Become Silent'?
subtitle: An oft-quoted statement attributed to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. appears to have been paraphrased from a speech he made in 1965.
author: David Emery
statement: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. said "Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about things that matter."

title: Did 30,000 Cows Freeze to Death in a Winter Storm?
subtitle: A story that thousands of cattle were left dead after a winter storm was from 2015, not 2017.
author: Dan Evon
statement: More than 30,000 cows froze to death during a winter storm because farmers could not be bothered to take care of their animals.

title: Did Donald Trump Engage the 'Russian Law Firm of the Year'?
subtitle: While a law firm working with Donald Trump was named "Russia Law Firm of the Year," this is not as unusual or alarming as some have made it out to be.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A law firm working with Donald Trump was named "Russia Law Firm of the Year."

title: Was a Man Sentenced to 22 Years in Prison Just for Stealing a TV Remote?
subtitle: While numerous outlets reported that an Illinois man was imprisoned for stealing a television remote control, the case was more nuanced than that.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A man was sentenced to 22 years in prison for stealing a remote control.

title: Did Gravity Payments CEO Dan Price Have to Rent His House to Make Ends Meet?
subtitle: Gravity Payments CEO Dan Price rented out his house after raising the minimum wage at his company to $70,000, but not because he couldn't otherwise make ends meet.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Gravity Payments CEO Dan Price rented his house in order to make ends meet after taking a $900,000 pay cut and raising the minimum salary at his company to $70,000.

title: Did Donald Trump Fire All Politically Appointed Ambassadors in an Unprecedented Move?
subtitle: While Trump's "no exceptions" policy for outgoing ambassadors is uncommon, the resignation and replacement of ambassadors at the end of an administration is routine.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Trump gave an unprecedented order for all politically appointed ambassadors to resign immediately.

title: Is Ordering an 'Angel Shot' Potentially Life-Saving for Women?
subtitle: It may be  better just to ask for help than to order an 'angel shot' if you're caught in an unnerving situation at a bar.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Women in a dangerous situation at a bar can order an angel shot to ensure safe passage into an Uber and away from a frightening man.

title: New Year's Superstitions
subtitle: Ring in 2020 with a compendium of superstitions associated with New Year's Day.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A variety of superstitions are associated with New Year's Day.

title: Social Security Recipients Barred from Owning Guns?
subtitle: A new Social Security Administration rule would extend gun background check reporting to some Social Security recipients.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A new Social Security Administration rule would bar Social Security recipients from owning guns.

title: What Is the Bottom Drawer of an Oven Really For?
subtitle: While many ovens have a warming drawer below the main compartment, this feature is not available on all models.
author: Dan Evon
statement: The bottom drawer on an oven can be used to keep food warm.

title: Did a Federal Judge Rule Police Can Legally Shoot and Kill Dogs?
subtitle: A widely misrepresented federal court ruling deemed that the shooting of two dogs during the execution of a search warrant was justified, but it did not give police sweeping authority to shoot and kill dogs.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The federal government passed a law permitting police officers to shoot dogs if they bark or move.

title: Are Diners Obligated to Pay Mandatory Gratuity or Tip Charges?
subtitle: The often unwelcome presence of precalculated "mandatory" gratuities have left diners confused about whether those fees are obligatory.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Diners are legally obligated to pay mandatory service charges or tips which appear on their checks.

title: Mitch McConnell Blocked New Bipartisan Panel From Investigating Russian Hacks?
subtitle: The senator said in a television interview that he thought existing committees were capable of investigating reported Russian hacks.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell blocked a bipartisan committee from investigating purported Russian hacks.

title: More Votes Than Voters in Detroit
subtitle: Precincts in Detroit showed more votes than voters due to inaccurate voter tallies by poll workers rather than voting fraud.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Multiple precincts in Detroit reported more votes than voters in the 2016 general election, suggesting voter or electoral fraud.

title: Trump Sons Sell Access to Father for Hunting Trip Fundraiser
subtitle: An invitation for a fundraising event stated that donors could meet Donald Trump and hunt with his sons.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Donald Jr. and Eric Trump sold access to their father via an expensive hunting fundraiser.

title: Are Cavities Contagious?
subtitle: Misinformation abounds about whether dental caries are contagious, based largely on a since-deleted press release.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Cavities are contagious, primarily between intimate partners or children and caregivers.

title: Russian Flag at Texas State Capitol
subtitle: A photograph showing a Russian flag on display at the Texas State Capitol has been shared widely without proper context.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A Russian flag was flown at the Texas State Capitol in celebration of Donald Trump's election.

title: Bee Venom Kills HIV
subtitle: Preliminary research has shown that a single compound found in bee venom can destroy HIV, but it takes nanoscale engineering to get the process to work effectively.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Bee sting venom can kill HIV.

title: Hillary Clinton's Popular Vote Win Came Entirely from California
subtitle: Hillary Clinton garnered 4.3 million more votes than Donald Trump in the nation's most populous state.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Hillary Clinton's popular vote win in the presidential election came entirely from the state of California.

title: Will a Vinegar and Water Mixture De-Ice Your Windshield?
subtitle: Spraying a mixture of vinegar and water on your car's windshield may help prevent the glass from frosting, but it probably won't help clear already iced-over glass.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Spraying a mixture of vinegar and water on your car's windshield will effectively help de-ice it.

title: Confessions for the Holidays
subtitle: Ben Stein's 2005 commentary about the observance of Christmas circulates every holiday season.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Transcript reproduces Ben Stein's television commentary about the observance of Christmas.

title: Plane Crash Video 'Disappearing From the Internet'?
subtitle: A 2013 video shows a cargo plane crashing in Afghanistan.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A video showing an airplane losing altitude and then crashing in Pakistan is "disappearing from the Internet."

title: Obama Urges Soldiers to Question Trump's Authority?
subtitle: During a speech at MacDill Air Force Base in Florida, President Obama said that Americans have the freedom to question authority and criticize any sitting president.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: President Obama told soldiers to question President-elect Trump's authority.

title: Did Liberals Demand an 'Offensive' WWI Memorial Be Torn Down?
subtitle: A popular meme about the Bladensburg Cross claimed that "liberals" were "offended" by the WWI memorial and demanded its removal.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Liberals were offended by a World War I memorial and demanded it be torn down.

title: Scientists Find an Australian Berry That Can Cure Cancer in 48 Hours?
subtitle: A chemical isolated from an obscure Australian berry has shown potential as a tumor-killing agent, and clinical trials are underway for its use in animals and humans.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Scientists have discovered a berry - found in only one region of Australia - that can cure cancer in 48 hours.

title: Emboldened by Election, Texas Republicans Kill Medicaid Funding for Children with Disabilities?
subtitle: A viral article inaccurately reported that Medicaid spending cuts in Texas affecting disabled children were thanks to "emboldened" state Republicans.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Republicans in Texas made significant cuts to Medicaid after they were "emboldened" by the results of the 2016 general election.

title: Are Feds Tracking Support for an Audit of Donald Trump?
subtitle: According to social media claims, Sen. Elizabeth Warren made the request from a non-partisan government agency.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The Government Accountability Office is tracking emails sent supporting an audit of Donald Trump requested by Sen. Elizabeth Warren.

title: The Life of Colonel Sanders
subtitle: Supposedly flat broke and suicidal at 65, KFC's Colonel Sanders parlayed his Kentucky-fried chicken recipe into a multi-billion-dollar business by age 88 - or did he?
author: David Emery
statement: Inspirational Internet postings recount the high and low points in the life of KFC founder Colonel Harland Sanders.

title: Can President Trump Send Unblockable Text Messages to Every American?
subtitle: Articles published in late 2016 speculated that soon-to-be President Trump could abuse an FCC alert system to pelt American mobile phones with "unblockable" text messages.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: President Trump has the right and the means to send unblockable text mesage to all American cellular phones.

title: Tim Kaine Blamed 'Gun Violence' for Ohio State Knife Attack?
subtitle: Sen. Tim Kaine's initial tweet about the Ohio State University attack was based on erroneous early news reports that the attacker had used a gun; he tweeted a correction after seeing updated stories.
author: David Emery
statement: Sen. Tim Kaine responded to news of a machete attack at Ohio State University by tweeting that he was deeply saddened by the senseless act of "gun violence."

title: DAPL Routed Through Standing Rock After Bismarck Residents Said No?
subtitle: As disputes and protests over the Dakota Access Pipeline continued, rumors appeared that the pipeline was re-routed after residents of Bismarck refused the risk.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: The Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) was re-routed through the Standing Rock Reservation after Bismarck's mostly-white residents refused to allow it near their water supply.

title: Will a Deadline of 1 January 2017 Kill the Dakota Access Pipeline?
subtitle: Both opponents and proponents say that stalling the pipeline until 1 January 2017 could make its construction unfeasible.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Protests could permanently halt the Dakota Access Pipeline by blocking construction until 1 January 2017, when the project's contracts expire.

title: Is Michigan About to Sell 100 Million Gallons of Groundwater to Nestlé for $200?
subtitle: A viral petition about the proposed sale of groundwater to Nestlé in Michigan lacked some context.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Michigan is about to sell 100 million gallons of groundwater to Nestlé for $200.

title: Meet Betsy DeVos, Trump's Secretary of Education Nominee
subtitle: The nomination of Betsy DeVos as secretary of education inspired an Internet meme detailing her alleged lack of qualifications for the job.
author: David Emery
statement: Donald Trump's nominee for Secretary of Education, billionaire Betsy DeVos, has no education degree or teaching experience, has never attended a public school or sent her children to one, and supports the funding of for-profit Christian schools over public ones; she got the job because she donated $9.5 million to Trump's campaign.

title: Trump to Strike Down Obama's Regulation Expanding Overtime?
subtitle: President Obama's expanded rule on overtime has been placed on hold, but by a judge, not incoming president Donald Trump.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Donald Trump plans to do away with a new regulation put in place by President Obama that expands overtime to more workers.

title: Are Jellyfish and Lobsters Biologically Immortal?
subtitle: Some jellyfish do meet the definition of biologic immortality, but lobsters do not make the cut.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Jellyfish and lobsters are considered biologically immortal, meaning they don't age and will never die unless they are killed.

title: Did the Trump Team Accidentally Reveal an 'Extreme' Immigration Plan?
subtitle: While one of Trump's potential cabinet picks unwittingly revealed his harsh immigration proposals, it is inaccurate to claim it's Trump's plan.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A document held by a potential Trump cabinet member reveals his immigration plans.

title: New York Police Take Rutgers Professor for Psychological Evaluation Over Political Tweet?
subtitle: Kevin Allred, who teaches women's and gender studies at Rutgers, said his First Amendment rights were violated when police detained him for a rhetorical tweet about shooting white people.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A Rutgers University professor was forced into a psychological evaluation due to political tweets.

title: Did Mike Pence Declare That Smoking Doesn't Kill?
subtitle: After Mike Pence was elected vice president,  a number of articles reported that he once asserted smoking doesn't kill people.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Mike Pence declared that smoking doesn't kill people.

title: Obama Permanently Protected Planned Parenthood from Defunding
subtitle: A proposed change to Title X family planning regulations preventing states from defunding Planned Parenthood goes into effect on 18 January 2017.
author: David Emery
statement: President Obama signed a law permanently protecting the federal funding of Planned Parenthood.

title: 'Black Mob' Beats White Man for Voting Trump?
subtitle: Chicago police said they are investigating an battery caught on video that stemmed from a traffic-related altercation - not from discussing politics.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A white man was beaten by a group of black people for voting Trump.

title: Mike Pence Tried to Jail Same-Sex Couples for Seeking Marriage Licenses?
subtitle: The Indiana governor, now Vice President-elect,  signed a bill penalizing anyone who  "knowingly solemnizes a marriage of individuals who are prohibited from marrying."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Mike Pence signed a bill barring same-sex couples from seeking marriage licenses in Indiana.

title: Don't Selfie Your Ballot?
subtitle: Is taking a photograph of your ballot and posting it online illegal?  Depends on where you live and how you do it.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Taking a photograph of your ballot and posting it to the Internet is illegal or will invalidate your vote.

title: 'Madam President' Hillary Clinton Newsweek Cover
subtitle: An image showing Hillary Clinton on the cover of a Newsweek publication under the title "Madam President" is real but is not proof that the news outlet colluded with the Clinton campaign prior to the 2016 presidential election.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A Newsweek-branded "Madam President" publication cover declared Hillary Clinton the winner of the presidential election prior to 8 November 2016.

title: Men Abandoned Male Birth Control Breakthrough Because of Side Effects?
subtitle: A preliminary study of a hormonal form of birth control for men was halted due to side effects commonly reported by women taking birth control, leading many to note an apparent double standard.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Men abandoned a groundbreaking study on male birth control due to side effects such as mood changes, muscle pain, and acne.

title: Voted Early for Hillary Clinton? Want to Change Your Mind?
subtitle: A somewhat misleading article suggested that several states were allowing people to change their votes in the light of an announcement by FBI director Jim Comey.
author: Dan Evon
statement: After FBI Director Jim Comey announced that he was reviewing e-mails potentially linked to Hillary Clinton, several states announced that they were allowing people to change their early votes.

title: Health Insurance Under the Affordable Care Act Costs Hundreds or Thousands Per Month?
subtitle: ACA costs are going up in 2017, but premium payments depend largely on the individual's income level.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Coverage under Obamacare can costs more than $1,200 a month for a family of four.

title: Did Mike Pence Support 'Gay Conversion' Therapy?
subtitle: While running for Congress, Indiana governor Mike Pence called for state funding for "institutions" working to enable people to "change their sexual behavior."
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Mike Pence supported "gay conversion" therapy, including the use of electroshock therapy.

title: Did Hillary Clinton Laugh at 'Under God' Being Removed from the Pledge of Allegiance?
subtitle: A video shows Hillary Clinton laughing as Susan Shin Angulo flubbed the words to the Pledge of Allegiance.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows Hillary Clinton laughing as the words "under God" were removed from the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Bill O'Reilly Telephone Poll of 25,000 Voters Shows Trump with a Huge Lead?
